urn:contentItem:5WJ6-H9H1-F0J6-J2CP-00000-00A changing of the business guard, as tech displaces finance A changing of the business guard, as tech displaces finance2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:35ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 22A changing of the business guard, as tech displaces finance A changing of the business guard, as tech displaces financeJohn McDuling

It's been difficult to avoid the impression this week that we are witnessing the end of an era in Australian business.

The nation's most powerful corporate deal maker of the past decade or so, UBS's local boss Matthew Grounds, announced his retirement. And one of the world's biggest investment banks, Deutsche Bank, began a significant retreat from Australia, where it has held a strong presence for 25 years.

The twin developments justifiably created a huge stir within the investment community. Such that another, perhaps equally significant business development, almost slipped by unnoticed.

Across the Pacific Ocean on the Nasdaq index, shares in Australia's most prominent tech company Atlassian hit fresh highs.

As this took place, co-founder Mike Cannon-Brookes was rubbing shoulders with the likes of Apple CEO Tim Cook, Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg and News Corp scion Lachlan Murdoch at the ultra-exclusive Allen & Co conference in Sun Valley, Idaho.

The share surge means Atlassian is a now a $50 billion company. In other words, it's more valuable than Telstra, the corporate icon Grounds helped float on the stockmarket, in what he described this week as one of his most memorable deals. It also means Cannon-Brookes (and co-founder Scott Farquhar's) fortune sits comfortably ahead of James Packer's - a corporate icon himself, and Grounds' most famous client.

"It's a surreal place to be for sure," Cannon-Brookes told me in a phone call on the sidelines of the event this week, referring to the rise of Atlassian. "But we are here. And I think we deserve to be here."

Now, as someone who started his career in finance (including a brief stint on a Deutsche Bank trading floor) and ended up writing about technology and media, I acknowledge I may be reading too much into things.

But this week's events still felt highly symbolic to me. Yet another striking illustration of a theme I see everywhere: technology is becoming a more prominent function inside many companies than finance (or at least internal corporate strategy and deal-making departments). And tech is displacing finance as the dominant business sub-culture.

The era of the deal maker, and the industrial moguls they advise, dressed in double-breasted suits and pounding the oak table in the boardrooms has all but faded. It is being replaced by the age of the hoodie-clad venture capitalist, and the freewheeling, disruptive tech entrepreneur.

This theory is not perfect, of course. Deal makers and financiers are making a lot of money from tech, and tech moguls are doing a lot of deals.

The conference Cannon-Brookes and other tech figures attended this week in Idaho is hosted by a boutique investment bank, after all.

Also, none of this is to say that tech's ascendancy is leading us into an era that is necessarily better than what preceded it. The tech industry has its fair share of problems, which are only coming to light now it is in the ascendancy. The too-big-to-fail bank has been usurped by the ungovernable tech giant.

Regulators and politicians are increasingly concerned about the market power of 'Big Tech' companies, not to mention the impact of their products on society. Facebook and Google, in particular, are under fire for repeated privacy breaches, failing to stop fake news and filter bubbles, and for absolving themselves of responsibility when deeply problematic content has spread on their platforms.

Unlike investment banks, tech companies can't be blamed for a global economic collapse. But the strong case can be made that some of them have seriously weakened democracies.

The shift from finance tech is real and unmistakeable though. And it is not just cultural. There is arguably a powerful macro trend underpinning it. Ultra-low interest rates have weakened the banks' profitability, but also enabled disruptive businesses that otherwise may not have existed to not just operate, but thrive. This raises an obvious question: what happens if and when interest rates return to more historically normal levels?

None of this is likely top of mind for Cannon-Brookes, though, who has truly arrived as a member of the global business elite. Not that you would know it from talking to him. "We have got a shit load of work to do," he says. "We will keep focused on the long term, building the best company we can. For customers ultimately, rather than shareholders, and the rest sort of takes care of itself."

Ruth It is not easy making a physical product—particularly when using biotechnology—and the results may be surprising.<nl/> That was the key message this past weekend from Jonathan Wolfson, co-founder and CEO of San Francisco-based Solazyme (NASDAQ: SZYM[1]) at the NYU Entrepreneurs Festival. At the event, Wolfson, an alumnus of the university, sat with me for a keynote fireside chat about Solazyme's origins and the company's current path.<nl/>

Solazyme produces renewable oil from microalgae for personal-care products, food ingredients, and industrial uses, along with making biofuel that has been tested by the military.<nl/> The company has seen its share of changes and some growing pains, including shifting its focus beyond its early plans for biofuels[2]. Solazyme also took some heat last year because of production delays at its plant in Brazil[3].<nl/> Despite such setbacks, he said the company is pursuing new partnerships and opportunities in industries that were not part of Solazyme's original game plan.<nl/> Xconomy: We're coming up on the anniversary of the founding of the company?<nl/> Jonathan Wolfson: This will formally be the 12th anniversary, coming up in a couple of weeks. But the idea goes back to 1989, where I met the guy, who I co-founded the company, on my first day of college.<nl/> XC: How did Solazyme come together; I hear it was founded literally in a garage?<nl/> JW: It's a little more complicated than that. That's the Silicon Valley garage story. While that's completely true, it followed lots of other things. We had been talking about starting a company to make renewable fuels from microalgae going back to the late 1980s. It took us a long time; we both did other things. I started another company [InvestorTree], a financial services firm here in New York.<nl/> After 14 years of talking about it, my friend was living in Palo Alto, I was in New York. I bought a $600 car on Craigslist, drove out to California, and moved in with him and his wife. We set up in the garage with a couple of hundred strings of algae, a futon, and some computers.<nl/> XC: Who did you feel you really had to convince that algae could be used this way and how did you sell them on the idea?<nl/> JW: There was what I thought the idea would be, what it is, and what it became along the way. Those aren't exactly the same thing. I think one of the most important things for either current entrepreneurs or people who are thinking about this is, one of the things that I learned between the first company I started and the second company was that you need to follow the opportunity. Initially the idea was to create low-carbon fuels. We're destroying our planet. There's a real need for low-carbon fuels and it turns out that microalgae were the original oil producers on the planet. They've evolved over billions of years to make oil. When you pull petroleum out of the ground, you can do molecular fingerprinting and demonstrate that a fair amount of that oil originated from microalgae.<nl/> The idea then was, 'How can we speed this up in real time using the tools of modern biotechnology?'<nl/> What ended up happening was the original technology didn't exactly work. We had to retrofit it. This was after we raised our first round of financing. Which led to some very 'exciting' discussions about convincing our early investors that although the original technology, growing algae in big covered ponds, didn't work early on, we arrived at the conclusion that algae was still the best platform to make oil. There was just a different way to do it.<nl/> For us it was industrial fermentation, which means big stainless steel tanks and plant-based sugars. Instead of asking the algae to do photosynthesis themselves, you feed them sugars from other plants that have done it, and then they make oil for you. We had to go back and pitch the initial investors on this idea of growing algae in the dark in big steel tanks. There wasn't that much money in the company, and these were Silicon Valley, risk-taking types. It turned out to work exceedingly well.<nl/> The second thing is if you're making oils, you don't necessarily have to be a company that's dedicated to fuel. Along the way we learned we can turn these oils into anything we use oils for today, from food to industrial applications like soaps, to cosmetics, home care products, and laundry detergents.<nl/> XC: When you started looking to these other segments, did you get concerned you were going in too many different directions?<nl/> JW: That's always been a serious and semi-valid criticism of Solazyme. Once we developed a platform that allowed us to make oils at large scale, and to tailor those oils, that the number of market opportunities we could go into created a lack of focus.<nl/> One of the things that entrepreneurs are forced to do constantly is to trim back lots of really good ideas to keep energy in a relatively narrow band. There's no question that if you try to do everything, you will fail.<nl/> XC: How much of a challenge was it to gather people to work with you on this?<nl/> JW: We had to convince a lawyer to do the legal work for us when we were raising money, and get paid only when money was raised. But that lawyer wouldn't do it unless you convinced them that the idea had currency. We wanted to bring in some advisors so that we could pressure-test the technology and market opportunities. We gave them stock options, but they had to believe those options would be worth something.<nl/> If you expand that out, it applies very heavily to employees and partners.<nl/> We decided very early on we couldn't go vertical in most of our markets. We had to focus on our technology core and being able to make things that could improve people's lives. We brought in a few people in business development in fuels. We were able to form a partnership with Chevron. We also brought in some experts on a consulting basis to help us work with the Pentagon. We ended up forming a huge partnership with the U.S. Navy.<nl/> Solazyme didn't have fuels competency, but we were able to leverage all the people at Chevron and we were able to leverage all the people in the Navy who had tremendous fuels expertise. They told us what we had to make and how. When were looking at personal care, we partnered with Unilever. For paints, we partnered with AkzoNobel.<nl/> XC: Are there misconceptions about biofuel and using microalgae in this way that you had to clear up for others?<nl/> JW: When we first started, I didn't know of another company working in microalgae specifically for fuels. Within a year or two, there were five. Within a couple more years, there were over 100. But they were trying to do the technology the way we originally started to do it. It was hard to explain to people that we were doing it differently.<nl/> We would go to conferences, and people with companies based on technology we had dismissed would give presentations saying you can't grow algae in stainless steel. That it leaches zinc from the stainless steel. We would spend hours with potential financing sources explaining that we were doing it every day.<nl/> We spent years getting to know analysts at consulting firms, having them come in and look at our technology and follow our progress.<nl/> XC: How much of a challenge has it been to scale up what you're doing? It's not like developing an app.<nl/> JW: There's a very substantial difference between building a piece of software or a Web-based service and making physical things. There's an astonishingly big difference. You need to understand that difference when you think about starting a company.<nl/> People look at some of the big tech companies and how they pay large amounts for what seems like somewhat unproven technology, applications, or websites. If you're on the knowledge side of the world, you need constant innovation, but you can get to market relatively quickly and start to generate revenue early. When you're making things, particularly in biotechnology, it takes much longer.<nl/> If you look at the Internet, mobile applications, or even computer hardware, there are investor communities that built up over time in each of these areas, and an investor community that built up around medical biotechnology.<nl/> The space that I'm in doesn't really have that core, investor community yet. It doesn't have that model of how businesses are valued the same way either. That timeline and scale-up, for us, is different.<nl/> We have to assemble very large amounts of capital. To develop this technology, Solazyme has raised over $500 million or $600 million in equity and debt financing from the capital markets. On top of that, we've raised project financing. We built a very large plant in Brazil. We got a low-interest loan from the Brazilian Development Bank. We partnered for a plant in Iowa with ADM (Archer Daniels Midland). Part of this is about taking a concept, proving it out, but if you make stuff you have to be able to make it at scale. That's hard. Sometimes you don't get the timeline that you want.<nl/> At two of our plants, we hit our timelines right on the money. At our biggest plant, in Brazil, it's taken longer to get that plant up. We went public to finance it, and when you go public to finance something, having those kinds of delays out in the open is painful.<nl/> But we're now in the market, for the first time, with many of our food products. We have these low-saturate oils that are healthy from a heart-health perspective. We have a personal care line called Algenist that's in every Sephora and on QVC. Even with all these products, it's been almost 13 years. We just got our key regulatory clearance in the U.S. for our food oil three weeks ago. For our protein and other applications, we got those regulatory clearances last year.<nl/> It's about understanding what you are getting into from the beginning. What do the timelines really look like, as opposed to what you hope they look like? And are you prepared to stay with it?<nl/> XC: Did you ever feel like you bit off more than you could chew? And was there a moment when you felt the company rounded a corner and started to feel more tangible?<nl/> JW: I felt like I bit off more than I could chew for the first five years of running this company. I don't have a technology background. I went to every lab meeting and it was my informal-formal education in biotechnology. There were plenty of times when I thought this was an enormously ambitious project. But that was one of the things that motivated the core people at Solazyme to get out of bed in the morning, taking on something big, hairy, ugly, and has the opportunity to make a huge impact.<nl/> In December 2007, we made our very first in spec fuels. And at the time in California, you couldn't buy a diesel passenger car. So our chairman, who financed us out of the garage, his wife had gone to Nevada and bought a diesel Mercedes. She volunteered to let us borrow her new diesel car and run our fuel in it. I remember fueling up the car, driving it, and thinking this might be doable.<nl/> Then we launched a cosmetic brand in 2011. Never expect that you're going to know what's coming. I never thought I'd be involved in personal care and anti-aging cosmetics.<nl/> The technology we found from the algae while making fuels was really by mistake. The algae made these compounds to protect themselves and it turned out they had really great impact from an anti-aging perspective.<nl/> It's a long road and we're not done.<nl/> XC: What do you see as the driver going forward for Solazyme?<nl/> JW: We are quietly selling fuel every day to a large fleet customer in the U.S. But with oil prices where they are, and being in the early stages of running our big plants, we're not at a place where I think this technology is going to be extremely, broadly adopted for fuel. Notwithstanding the fact that the environmental footprint is dramatically better and we've demonstrated that the Navy could certify an entire fleet of ships and planes running on this stuff.<nl/> Down the line, the fuels will be a very significant component. Right now they are a smaller part of what we do. Food is going to be very important for us, personal care will continue to be, and the Algenist brand continues to grow every year.<nl/> Comments[4] | Reprints[5] | Share: urn:contentItem:5SJS-XCP1-J9XT-P04B-00000-00Achieving Financial Inclusion: Fintech, account usage, and innovation2018-06-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:35ZLexisNexisAchieving Financial Inclusion: Fintech, account usage, and innovation

Washington: The World Bank Group has issued the following news release: For almost a decade, the global community and national governments have made concerted efforts to expand financial inclusion—creating a financial system that works for all and opens the doors to greater stability and equitable progress. This has been a demanding challenge. At the start of our engagement on financial access back in 2013, we said that having a real target with an end date would keep us focused and give us a benchmark against which we could measure progress. Last month we learned that we have made strong and consistent progress—a real cause for celebration.

According to the Global Findex database, more than half a billion people gained a financial transaction account over the last three years, thanks to a combination of technology, private investment, policy reforms, and support from the global community. Since 2011, the share of adults with formal accounts has risen from 51 percent to 69 percent, and financial access has expanded to include an additional 1.2 billion people. The Global Findex has helped national governments and development organizations understand how people use their accounts, where the gaps are, and how to target interventions. Its insights are central to the World Bank Group’s Universal Financial Access 2020 initiative, a global commitment to ensure that all adults have access to an account by 2020. Since we announced the initiative in 2013, the World Bank Group has added more than 30 partners across the financial sector to help reach this important goal. The Bank Group also remains on target to achieve its commitment to reach 1 billion new accountholders by 2020 through its work. From access to use But access isn’t enough. What matters is whether and how people use financial services. The point of financial inclusion, after all, is not just for people to possess an account but to use it to escape poverty, recover from setbacks, and improve their well-being. The story that emerges from the latest Findex is one of digital technology’s impact on both access and usage. The example of mobile money in Kenya is well known: today, more than 70 percent of Kenyans use their mobile phones to make transactions from their mobile money accounts. In Mongolia, mobile money account ownership rose from less than 5 percent to around 20 percent. The rise of fintech innovations, especially internet-enabled payments, is the second big tech story. In China, account owners using the internet to pay bills or make purchases jumped from 24 percent to 57 percent. With the internet and e-commerce comes big data, which is making credit more accessible for small firms in a growing number of markets. To have and have-not The new Findex data also carries a cautionary message. Our progress so far has been uneven—women, the poor, and people out of the workforce are being left behind. Despite overall progress, the gaps between haves and have-nots remain as wide as they were when we began to measure in 2011. Sixty-five percent of women now have an account, up from 58 percent in 2014, but the gap between women and men remains a persistent 9 percentage points in developing countries. In Bangladesh, 36 percent of women have an account compared to 65 percent of men, a difference of 29 percentage points. In Pakistan, a man is five times more likely to open an account than a woman. To close these gaps, we need to understand what women need and want from financial services. We understand that they prioritize privacy, low cost, and security; but we need to do a better job of recognizing how women’s and men’s financial goals differ and identify products and approaches that can help eliminate the gender gap. This customer-centric perspective brings us again to the challenge of usage. Currently, one in five accounts is dormant, with neither a deposit nor a withdrawal in the past 12 months. Inactive account rates vary across regions but are especially high in South Asia. Understanding the pain points of women, the poor, farmers, and other excluded people will be critical for designing both new services and new regulations. The ability to digitally depositing payments directly into accounts would be a great springboard for people to open and use accounts. Digitizing government payments, for example, could improve financial inclusion among women by up to 20 percentage points in the Philippines and 28 points in Chile. Doing the same with agricultural payments could reduce the number of unbanked by up to a quarter in Mozambique, Nigeria, and Vietnam. And digitizing wages could bring in about 230 million unbanked people who are paid in cash. Remittances are another promising arena: roughly 280 million account owners in developing economies still use cash or over-the-counter services to send or receive remittances, including 10 million people in Bangladesh and 65 million in India. Innovation in the lead New technologies will improve digitization and reduce the cost of providing financial services. For example, e-money regulations in Senegal, coupled with digitization policies, opened up the market to more e-money issuers and increased financial access. Findex data show that the share of unbanked adults fell to 58 percent in 2017 from 85 percent in 2014, as a result of reforms and increased competition. Other interventions involve improving infrastructure—for example issuing digital IDs. When people can prove who they are digitally, financial institutions are much more likely to let them open an account. We are also looking to the future to see the impact of blockchain, artificial intelligence, and other fintech innovations that have the potential to reconfigure the entire value chain for financial services. But we need to strike a balance between unleashing fintech innovations, managing risk and stability, and protecting consumers—especially the poor. Some countries are grappling with this in interesting ways. Malaysia and Kenya are setting up regulatory sandboxes, which allow regulators to observe innovations in a controlled live environment to better understand potential risks and opportunities. Mexico and the Philippines are experimenting with RegTech—applying technology to simplify the cost and time for regulatory compliance and oversight. Recognizing that financial inclusion can strengthen economies, reduce inequality, and help millions of people lift themselves out of poverty, many countries have established national financial inclusion strategies. These approaches bring together financial regulators, telecommunications and competition authorities, social welfare and education ministries, and the private sector to coordinate and accelerate financial inclusion efforts. We have made a lot of progress since we started tracking global financial inclusion. Millions of people have gained the chance to improve their lives. We must continue to work together – governments, development organizations, civil society, and the private sector – to make sure that number continues to grow. urn:contentItem:5T4Y-G0X1-F021-61CB-00000-00A child in every classroom has received a naked image2018-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:36ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1A child in every classroom has received a naked imageMark Bridge, Technology Correspondent

One child in every British primary school class on average has been sent a naked or semi-naked image by an adult online, a survey suggests.

The poll of nearly 40,000 children aged 7 to 16 by the NSPCC also found that one in fifty had sent such an image to an adult. The charity has launched a petition calling on Sajid Javid, the home secretary, and Jeremy Wright, the digital secretary, to "tame" big tech and stop children being groomed and abused online.

The survey, the largest of its kind, found that children were accustomed to being contacted by adults seeking to groom them on apps, games and websites. Campaigners say this is possible because tech companies do not enforce age restrictions. About 600,000 British children under Facebook's "minimum age" of 12 are on the social network, according to the research company Emarketer, and apps available from Google and Apple's app stores have been criticised for enabling grooming.

One ten-year-old girl told the survey: "A complete stranger asked me to take my clothes off and send him a picture . . . When I deleted the game, I went on another site and the same person asked me to have sex with him. I told him to 'back off' and then deleted that game. I have seen this person on many sites that I play and I decided to block him." At secondary school even more children reported that adults had sent them nude or semi-nude images, with one in twenty aged 12 to 16 saying they had received such a picture.

Children said the problem was not limited to strangers and some had been sent images by adults they knew. A boy aged 15 said: "My [sports] coach sent me a video of Santa stripping naked."

Others reported that the exchange of sexual images, often known as sexting, was becoming normalised One pupil aged 13 said: "A girl from my primary [was] sending half-naked pictures because it's what everyone does."

The NSPCC's Wild West Web campaign is calling on ministers to create an independent regulator to force social networks to find groomers.

A new crime of sexual communication with a child came into force in April last year in England and Wales, and within 12 months there had been more than 3,000 recorded offences, the charity found through freedom of information requests. Facebook, Instagram or Snapchat were used in 70 per cent of cases where police recorded such information.

Peter Wanless, chief executive of the NSPCC, said: "Grooming can no longer be shrugged off as secondary to other online crimes . . . Social networks have become a gateway for child abuse."

urn:contentItem:5T50-58J1-JCBX-G44N-00000-00A child in every classroom has received a naked image2018-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11A child in every classroom has received a naked imageMark Bridge

One child in every British primary school class on average has been sent a naked or semi-naked image by an adult online, a survey suggests.

The poll of nearly 40,000 children aged 7 to 16 by the NSPCC also found that one in fifty had sent such an image to an adult. The charity has launched a petition calling on Sajid Javid, the home secretary, and Jeremy Wright, the digital secretary, to "tame" big tech and stop children being groomed and abused online.

The survey, the largest of its kind, found that children were accustomed to being contacted by adults seeking to groom them on apps, games and websites. Campaigners say this is possible because tech companies do not enforce age restrictions. About 600,000 British children under Facebook's "minimum age" of 12 are on the social network, according to the research company Emarketer, and apps available from Google and Apple's app stores have been criticised for enabling grooming.

One ten-year-old girl told the survey: "A complete stranger asked me to take my clothes off and send him a picture ... When I deleted the game, I went on another site and the same person asked me to have sex with him. I told him to 'back off' and then deleted that game. I have seen this person on many sites that I play and I decided to block him." At secondary school even more children reported that adults had sent them nude or semi-nude images, with one in twenty aged 12 to 16 saying they had received such a picture.

Children said the problem was not limited to strangers and some had been sent images by adults they knew. A boy aged 15 said: "My [sports] coach sent me a video of Santa stripping naked."

Others reported that the exchange of sexual images, often known as sexting, was becoming normalised One pupil aged 13 said: "A girl from my primary [was] sending half-naked pictures because it's what everyone does."

The NSPCC's Wild West Web campaign is calling on ministers to create an independent regulator to force social networks to find groomers.

A new crime of sexual communication with a child came into force in April last year in England and Wales, and within 12 months there had been more than 3,000 recorded offences, the charity found through freedom of information requests. Facebook, Instagram or Snapchat were used in 70 per cent of cases where police recorded such information.

Peter Wanless, chief executive of the NSPCC, said: "Grooming can no longer be shrugged off as secondary to other online crimes ... Social networks have become a gateway for child abuse."

JOHN KRAFT, VP OF IR & STRATEGIC ANALYSIS, ACI WORLDWIDE, INC.: (presentation)

Good morning, everybody. We've got a packed house here, I think our decision to move to New York was a good one.

Welcome, and welcome to everybody on the webcast. For those of you I haven't met, my name is John Kraft, I run Investor Relations for ACI. We've got a lot of things to talk about today, and we're very excited to be here to talk about it. First off, we're going to have Phil Heasley, our CEO, discuss the company at a high level, and then we're going to dig a little deeper with Craig Saks, our COO, and Mike Braatz, our Chief Solutions and Marketing Officer.

From there, we'll talk about the financial opportunity with Scott Behrens, our CFO, and then we'll dive deeper into each of our 6 solutions and 4 target markets that we are catering to. We actually have some customers here as well as some partners. We're very lucky, we will hear from them. We also have a couple of demos, so we will do those as well, and then finally, at the end, we'll have plenty of time for Q&A so please save your Q&A towards -- to the end. And then for those of you in New York, we'll have lunch in the back room there and then we'll have our solution breakouts after that.

With that, I'll turn it over to Phil.

PHILIP GEORGE HEASLEY, CEO, PRESIDENT & DIRECTOR, ACI WORLDWIDE, INC.: Thanks, John. Good morning, everyone. I want to thank you coming at 08:30 in Manhattan, being past New Yorker, it's a lot to ask people to start at 08:30 in the morning, so thank you for being here. I have 3 objectives this morning, I'm not going to spend a lot of time -- I'm not going to be up here for a long time. One is, I want to, as John did, I want to thank everyone for coming and then I want to say hello. My second objective is that I am actually going to be saying goodbye, so this is the last time that you guys get to pick on me until I'm going to be leaving ACI. I announced my retirement a couple of weeks ago, and before I do, I want to take you through same conversation that we've had almost every single Analyst Day, so if you've been here over the years, I'm going to take you through the same structure that we've gone through for the last, say, 12 years, and it's about the transformational journey of control, profitability and growth.

We've kind of done it backwards in terms of how we do it, but the concept that initiated this whole activity that's now ACI is that we believed in digital commerce, and we believed in real time 15 years ago, and you'll say, well, what's the big deal, except most of the world thought the Internet, at that point, was a novelty and a good way of distributing porn, right? And there wasn't really -- it's not viewed the way it's -- the way it's viewed today, and if any of you have read the recent book called the Revenge of the Goliath (sic) [Goliath's Revenge] it's a great book because it says that most of the winners in the new digital age could very well be the people who were successful in the last turn, but they have to reinvent themselves and they've got the assets, but they have to make those assets relevant in a digital world.

And we believed in that a long time ago, and we have gone through the process of investing very, very heavily, starting off with the machine-dependent set of software, and we are now sitting here today with machine-independent software, as a matter of fact, the concept of hardware playing a major role in the digital world is no longer exists, it's having the ability to create a payment, in our case it's about payment and then being able to -- for it to have a beginning and an end, so you have to have -- you have to be able to take any kind of payment and deliver it to any kind of location. We've worked on that for a long time, and we also understood that the hub-and-spoke, peer-to-peer structure of payments in a SaaS then cloud world was going to land up changing and it wasn't going to be about the hub-and-spoke anymore, it was going to be about this whole network, fiber effect of payments. Therefore, you're going to basically have to do any payment, every possibility, which has become our -- which become our tagline and whatnot. In order to do that, we've spent a lot of money on R&D over the last 15 years. We've made over 20 acquisitions, and we haven't been an aggregator, we've been an integrator, which is extremely painful because when you aggregate things, you're still being a tribute to the past. When you integrate them, you take them apart and you put them back together in a way that's going to work going forward.

We've really changed the economics of payments and we haven't necessarily changed that in a way that makes all shareholders thrilled with us at the moment, but they should be. A term you're going to hear more and more and more in the next 1, 3, 5 years is about take rate. And take rate is how much does what you do in a payment, what you get paid to do that. And historic payments, they earn something around 30 basis points of take rate, so you say with the financial thing, so what do they earn? They earn about 30. If you look at all the new immediate payment schemes and whatnot going on around the world, there is probably room for 10 to 12 basis points of take rate, so there has to be productivity. Productivity is going to have to bring itself to this payments arena, and I think we're going to be faced with 2 phenomena. I think we're going to have about [1/10] the players in some not-so-distant future, and we're going to have about 10x the volumes that we have right now. So it may be 7 and it may be whatever, but directionally, that's the way it's going to go. And if you look at what's taking place in these horizontal mergers and you look at what's taking place in terms of changing behavior of Visa, Mastercard, and then may be even more importantly, you look at the change that's taking place in the banks, the banks are playing much more utility role and they're being relegated to dealing effectively with their good funds. And of course, that's their primary role. Visa, Mastercard and certainly Mastercard has -- I'm not stating anything, they wouldn't state at their own Analyst Day, is they're seeing credit card and debit card as being 2 of probably 15 or 20 different ways people are going to be able to pay over time, and they want to morph themselves into a very primary -- instead of being a branding element of that point of sale, they want to be a major player at that point of sale. The banks have all begun to move their merchant acquiring from being subordinate activities to their cards to they becoming primary activities of treasury management, so what does that mean? That means that the banks now realize that who they're really representing at the point of sale is the merchant or the corporation who is participating in that sale.

This, by the way, is nothing different than we said what's going to happen 12 years ago when we were talking to you guys, you all thought we were nuts at that point. That's really going to not only change the economics, but your value chain is not going to look like, right now, you do a payment, and you don't know how many times it touches other kinds of things, and I would say that in very short order, in years, but short order, the participants at the sale are going to be good funds, the branded driver of the payment and personally selling the goods. So that's what's going to confront the customer. It's really going to change what's taking place. Now you're going to see some presentations later on today and I would really spend a lot of your attention, if you really want to concentrate on one, concentrate on what's going on in India, because it is probably the blueprint for what's taking place in the payments, and people say, well, it's kind of one-off. It's not very much one-off. Why do Facebook and Google do so well at what they do? Because they present something to the mass market, which is free to the mass market, and they derive their value in terms of the participants who want to enjoin themselves in terms of that. India is really -- has really reinvented their payment system in a way that almost works the way Google would work or as matter of fact, they use Google and Facebook and whatnot in terms of making it happen. So that's one I would really take a look at because it's really, really going to change. And this key change that we are in is it's happening. I always told some of you guys, I didn't want to let go of this activity till we actually -- the Exodus was actually complete that we actually saw the new -- of the new activity taking place. And I think we see it. In the U.S., it's a little bit hidden because whereas U.S. banks have been told, you got to do immediate payments and they built you immediate payment infrastructure into the Clearinghouse and then no one has built a use case to actually use it in an effective kind of way. It's kind of frustrated the government and I guess they're claiming to build their own kinds of -- but you're not -- it's -- you really don't, if the Clearinghouse doesn't do it, it's going to happen by itself anyhow and if I were Visa, Mastercard, I would say, well, how do I do it, and then there's some other players that got very strong switching kinds of activities. Are we going to move? Thank you. Right. I always like to put these 2 up every time we do one of these because these haven't changed, our vision and our mission have not changed and a lot of what you're going to see today are going to go through cases and progress as it relates to it, but the concept that you're going to be able -- a payment is going to be the choice of not only what you use to pay is going to be your choice, how that payment transforms itself is going to land up being something that is totally visible to you, and I don't think we're going to go through the data privacy elements that -- of the Indian, but when India was reinventing their payment system, the first thing they did was, they thought through data privacy. And they said these are the rules you got to do from a data privacy standpoint and as long as you follow these rules, then you're not going to get in trouble in terms of how we reinvent payments, which is little bit different than Europe, where in Europe, they said, okay, we don't need to involve the people who have data, we're just going to tell them what the rules are and whatnot, and we're going to give the people the ability to choose or not choose. Well, it's kind of interesting and the Indian one that kind of gave everyone a standard, so to speak whatnot, but in the case of Europe, I don't know if you know, I think they're up to 93%, have opted in, so the whole concept of restricting that data is not working the way that people thought it was going to -- is not going to work the way people thought it was going to take place.

So Craig Saks is going to come up here, and he is going to start taking you into the meat and potatoes and before I get us into the introduction of him, I do want to tell you guys that my departure is not a departure that leaves us with any weakness in resource. We have a very, very strong management team here, with the exception of Eve, who is going to present to you later, was only been with us for 3 years. The average tenure of the executive team is 10, probably 10, 11 years with people here, 15 and people here as little as 8, 9. And it's a very talented team. When I went through control, profitability, growth, we are really at the place in transformation that -- I think you know our software has been taken off the mainframe, it's been put on the cloud and it runs, not -- without changing a line of code. We're at the point now that we have to address the opportunity that will be created by scale, because our software can do a lot more than our resources. We've got to get people to want to come to our door, you are going to hear about a partnership with Azure today, which is going to be a good example of it, and we have the team that can propel the growth that we need.

I'm a transformation guy, and I have no qualms about it. I like to go take things from one thing and bring them to the other. My forte is not going around and doing 54 partnerships with 23 different kinds of go-to market kind of capabilities, but this team's ability to go and execute on what we have is very real and they are very, very talented.

And with that, I'm going to introduce Craig Saks, who is our Chief Operating Officer and he'll start taking you through the meat and potatoes. Thanks, Craig.

CRAIG S. SAKS, SENIOR EVP & COO, ACI WORLDWIDE, INC.: Thanks very much, Phil. Thank you. All right. Thank you very much, Phil. We are all very excited about the next phase of the journey and achieving that growth that Phil has spoken about off the wonderful platform that we've built that is ACI today that is highly relevant in the changing world of payments, and we'll spend some time on that. Also like to reiterate our welcome to everyone here in New York and on the webcast, for those of you that have been with us and old friends for a very long time, thank you for your ongoing support, for the many new people that have joined us, thank you for your interest in what we do.

We trust that you'll have a very good morning, and that you'll find real value in the conversation. Windfall had the sea change slide up. If don't know if you noticed that, that's really nice little icon of a boat, the sailboat, and I think that's a great analogy for a lot of the conversation this morning. Countries that had a strong maritime capability in the past were actually significantly advantaged in terms of their ability to explore the world, discover new lands and build great wealths for their nations. And in many respects, it's exciting to think about the ACI that we've built as being a stronger ship that I think can sail forth into growth, into innovation and driving real value for everyone involved in ACI, so that's great.

Given the fact that, that a number of people and you, we thought we would start just with an overview of ACI. And all for those of you that have been with us for 15 years. You find 1 or 2 things that are fresh insights, but we'll discuss a little bit of what we do. First of all, these are the numbers in terms of who and what we are and how we show up around the world. And there are some really interesting stats there. But you need to frame those in the context of our core opportunity and our main opportunity. Our core strategy, rather, then our main opportunity, which is really this notion that Phil spoke about of real-time any to any payment. ACI has been very successful at putting ourselves in the center of what is a major transformational move in the world of payments over the next decade or 2, which is real-time payments and the ability to pay anyone across the global ecosystem. And you'll hear a lot more about that and how we do see ourselves as being in a very good position and well advantaged in that. Lastly, the point I do want to make is Request for Payment actually isn't a payment. Request for Payment is a message that then results in an ultimate payment happening, okay?

So let's go ahead and do the demo. You always get an insight to someone's life when you see their home screen, so let's go straight out of there. And what we'd do is we'll tap to start and get on with it. Now at this point, I'm actually representing the merchants portal, so this is an e-commerce merchant. So we're online, but just as simply, we could also be in a bricks-and-mortar store, where, ultimately, the Request for Payment can also happen in real time. Now in an e-commerce merchant, typically, someone will have registered with their email address, they would have given their mobile phone numbers. What they haven't given at any point are their account details. So that's where alias databases work in the background, in the clearing and settlement mechanisms, to link those e-mail addresses, those phone numbers into those account details and give access, but without having to provide those account details to the merchant themselves. But the only person that knows the banking details is the bank.

So let me go ahead and pretend I'm registering here. This is where my typing skills let me down, so just bear with me. I'll even use a real email address. Will be ACI, aren't we? Select the country. It would be so much easier when we've left the EU, the United Kingdom, because we'll be right at the top. We're renaming the country to simply say alone. We're down here somewhere. Here we go. There we found them. So we'll sign up to marketing because I want to be part of that 93% that Phil referred to. So here we go. So here we are, we're in the merchant site, and we're going to buy some rather snazzy ACI socks. So I'm going to select the pair of socks, there they are. They're EUR 5.99, very nice too. And at the bottom, I'm still in the merchant site, and it's asking about how do I want to checkout. And one of the opportunities is to checkout with a real-time payment. Now the merchant might prefer to use that versus a card or any other type of payment because it can give them some benefits. It might reduce their interchange fees, they can also get instant and real-time access to liquidity. And what I mean by that is the payment, because it's an account-to-account transfer, will instantly go across into that merchant's bank account. Now for a pair of socks, I'm guessing they're not going to be too worried. 1 million pairs of socks, it makes a big difference or high-end hi-fi or any other large purchases where retailers can actually reduce their stock inventory by having real-time access to funds. They can then resend that on instantly to a factory and get things shipped from a factory. So they're not having to hold as much stock.

So we're going to go ahead and press yes I'm going to do that real-time checkout. Now at this point, this is where the financial intermediary and the APIs kick in. The financial intermediary supporting that merchant said, thank you very much, we're going to now look at ways of making that real-time payment. And they will hook up to the different banking system's APIs. And we've got our fictitious bank, PD Bank & Trust, sitting out there ready to do a real-time payment. So I'm going to say, yes, I want to pay with them. And you'll notice that the user experience has now changed. I've actually moved now into my bank's portal, accessible over the API. And instantly, I feel more comfortable. This is a place I recognize. This is a banking experience I recognize. So I'm going to go ahead and select the account I want to use and I'm going to pay with real time. It's going to run through the biometrics of the phone. So again, I feel nice and comfortable that it is happening according to the experience that I expect. Success, the payment has happened. Return to merchant, and now I'm back at the merchant website. The payment has been successful and the socks are shipping. And miraculously, I do believe the socks have arrived. I mean that's instant and real time. Now I know what you're thinking. That's a great user experience, and it's a way that we can actually show that end-to-end ecosystem going on with real time. The other thing, too, you'll be delighted to know, socks, if you'd give me your EUR 6, ignore anyone else outside telling me differently, I'll accept dollars as well. You'll find socks in the lobby during lunch. Please help yourselves to pairs.

EVANTHIA C. ARETAKIS: Thanks, Craig. Okay. So just in wrap up, I think throughout the applications that you've seen today and the user experiences and the verticals that we provide solutions to, you can see a lot of the underlying technology at work. So first, user experience. Through a lot of the apps, you can see that we make that very convenient and seamless, and allow our customers to integrate to their user experience, their front ends as well as present a logical way that they can plug-and-play with the pieces we provide. We obviously have a number of powerful services that you can see deployed: our [e-cover] solution powering online payments for merchants, Payment Intelligence (sic) [Payments Intelligence] for fraud screening, and a number of other very important characteristics and capabilities that you saw through a number of the solutions and demos today. Obviously, the mobile SDK, it powers the mobile apps. At the point of the payment, the consumer is able to use our real-time payment and other types of payment types and integrate those seamlessly into their offers.

You can also see that we can support a number of devices, whether those devices are coming in with mobile, and depending on where you are around the world, how those are integrated into overlay services. Jeremy talked about Mindgate where you can integrate into some of their overlay services so you can integrate the payment type in WhatsApp as well as some of the other services that are prevalent in the Indian marketplace.

And then, of course, the APIs that allow us to create a frictionless set of services but also a wealth of opportunity for our customers to leverage pieces of software that we have already built, and be able to apply differentiation to that software to solve either a vertical or customer problem. It's a great example of how we intend to roll out these new services and make them extendable in reach to all of our verticals. So this is a great example of how ACI's Any Payment, Every Possibility at work, and hopefully, a way that you can see what we're creating for what's next. So now I'll turn it back over to John Kraft for the Q&A session. Thank you.

Questions and Answers

JOHN KRAFT: Thanks, Eve. Exciting stuff. It's now time for the Q&A. I'd like to ask Phil and Scott and Craig to come to the stage. It's your opportunity to ask questions to all three.

DAVID LUKE ELLER, ASSOCIATE ANALYST, WELLS FARGO SECURITIES, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: David Eller from Wells Fargo, back here in the back. I have 2 questions. Before we get started, I was glad to see the Wells Fargo card in the slides, glad to be a proud partner of you guys. Craig, in your talk, you talked about the growth of subscription payments, e-commerce. You mentioned streaming companies, razor blade companies. Can you give us a little flavor for some of the logos that you've won that maybe have been publicly disclosed? And then also for the logos that haven't come over yet, like what are the impediments to getting those on your platform? And then my second question is on cash flow. You talked -- you reiterated your guidance for this year for EBITDA and cash flow. Could you give us an idea of what that cash flow number might look like next year as we reach that $425 million to $445 million of EBITDA? And how are you going to spend the cash flow?

CRAIG S. SAKS: Right. Those are 2 very different questions. So we haven't disclosed a lot of logos on the subscription side. Suffice to say that we've got a very long or a good plan over the next few years. The one that we have discussed, we actually mentioned in our earnings call last week. Lime Light is an e-commerce platform. They do subscription life cycle management, and they've actually integrated with us and have selected us to provide the e-commerce payments behind their subscription life cycle management. So that's probably the best example that I would throw out at this stage.

SCOTT W. BEHRENS: Regarding cash flow, I would say, next year, we should convert about a consistent percentage of EBITDA to cash as we are this year. Regarding uses of cash, I think we're going to be consistent with what we've done historically, probably about 1/3 of our cash on share buybacks. We were in -- in Q3, we had an opportunity to get back in 1/3 on debt service and then 1/3 on opportunistically looking at tuck-in type acquisitions.

BRETT RICHARD HUFF, MD, STEPHENS INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Over here. This is Brett Huff from Stephens. Thanks for having us all here. This is a great day, as always. Two quick questions. One, Scott, you mentioned that kind of mid-single to high single-digit growth rate over time. In the past, it's been near-term low, medium term mid and long term high. Was there a nuance in there that we were supposed to take from that? Or is it very much the same?

SCOTT W. BEHRENS: Yes, I think it's the same. I don't -- the whole point of showing it by the 6 solutions versus looking at it in total, is we do have solutions that are at double-digit growth already. So it's really about taking the biller business, moving the needle a little bit, and that's a big part of the business, will help drive us towards high single digit. So the point was really saying we're not -- not all 6 solutions really need to move the needle that much. We really need to do it on biller. We need to do it in terms of refresh cycle with our customers on the retail payments, and we need to see digital start to stem its attrition rate. So nothing to read into that other than just saying, we just have to move the needle a little to bit until we get to those longer-term targets.

BRETT RICHARD HUFF: Okay. And then second question, on free cash flow. Free cash flow has been choppy over the years for good reasons. Can you tell us, will that free cash flow get a little bit more consistent with how EBITDA growth happens? And how do we get there from the choppiness maybe that we've had in the past? What's changed?

SCOTT W. BEHRENS: Well, I think on the licensed software side of the business, we're always going to have the choppiness. And there's really 2 components for that. One is fourth quarter is heavy with renewals, so it's heavy with both -- with billings. And then we have an annual cycle for a lot of the product support fees that are paid annually and then recognized on a recurring basis. But I'd say, with the addition of Speedpay and its, call it, $90 million of annual EBITDA, and that's recurring revenue, it's recurring margin, and it's highly recurring on a cash flow basis. So just the mere layer on of Speedpay is going to smooth out more of that cash flow because it's all in AOD business.

GEORGE FREDERICK SUTTON, PARTNER, CO-DIRECTOR OF RESEARCH & SENIOR RESEARCH ANALYST, CRAIG-HALLUM CAPITAL GROUP LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: George Sutton. First, I want to say thank you to Dan. I feel a lot better having 4 kids in various forms of higher education. You call them payment opportunities. I feel a lot better about that. So I think the word of the day is scale and the ability to potentially scale. There were 2 things that were brought up that I thought were very interesting relative to that and that was partnerships and integrations. I wondered if you could talk about kind of where you are there today. And then also, I think it was Phil that mentioned, you envision 1/10th of the number of players in the industry over time, but 10x the volume. And I just want to make sure I understood ACI in that future.

PHILIP GEORGE HEASLEY: So do you want to talk about the partnerships, and I'll talk about (inaudible).

CRAIG S. SAKS: All right. So to the question on partnerships. We've got a whole diversity of partnerships. It's actually amazing, the ecosystem has been bought around ACI globally. We've got lots of implementation partners that take care of some of the implementations and help us there. We have partners at that extreme, for example, you heard Microsoft talking about cloud, and that's a very important set of partnerships. And then within each of our solutions, we actually have a myriad of partnerships. So if you look at the bill payment space, for example, we have a large number of integrations into the back office ERP systems to give you that end-to-end customer life cycle experience by being able to get to the bill data. And so in all the different verticals we work in, we've got some key partners. So for example, in the mortgage servicing space, Black Knight is a partner; in the higher education, Ellucian is a partner; and so on. So in the biller space, a lot in our merchant solutions, we work with a number of the point-of-sale providers and so on. In our retail payment solutions, we've got a number of partners that would provide complementary services, and the list goes on and on and on. The bottom line is the whole point about openness and ability to provide end-to-end solutions where you're able to integrate and provide a seamless experience, like you saw and heard earlier on, is an important part of the model, and will continue to do so.

PHILIP GEORGE HEASLEY: Is [Shirley] here? Shirley , can we put the slide up that we didn't go through in my presentation? Right. Saved it for the last. All right. Because I do want to talk about -- this whole endeavor on ACI's part the last 15 years, part of what we've gone after is scale. And the chart is up here. Now we talked about the transformational journey that we've been on. When we started this thing, I had a list of 19 companies that were in the payments business, the way payments were being done as we came into this new century, right, early 2000s. And if you were to look at most of those, you look at that '19, 10 of them are gone. The 9 that exist are 40% to 60% the size they were when it began, and that's the likes of Hewlett-Packard, and that's the likes of a lot of players in the industry. And they've done a really kind of good job of ratcheting themselves down and whatnot in terms of have they beaten their quarters. One thing that I would like to do as part of this answer is thank all of you guys who have invested in us for 12, 15 years and whatnot. And had probably allowed us to miss, what's a fair number, Craig? Craig and Scott? 50% of our quarters? Or 40%? Because we are a transformational business that's actually building future value versus one that's trying to have 90 days of consistency. And if you look at it on a 10-year basis, you'd say, gee, this is a great thing to invest in.

If you look at it in terms of saying, how do you take the lumpiness out? How do you do this? You don't in a transformational business and whatnot, and Phil Bruno, who I think is here from McKenzie's, sent me an encouraging note that 70% of transformations fail. So maybe that's why The Street doesn't look at -- we get compared to revenue growth at any price. Well, a lot of what we're doing is we're restructuring the industry. And it's not growing organic revenue that really lands up being what allows us to survive, but it's the heavy investment in integration and building a set of outcomes for the future. Look at what this management team has produced. The only thing that slows down growth at this point is the industry's adoption of a future that we know is coming. A really germane question would be, well, who are your 3 competitors that if you don't sell it, someone else is going to end up selling it? Well, in some of our categories, yes, we have competitors in bill pay, but not competitors against the front end, back end kind of a platform that we're building. Yes, we have competitors that can clip at our toes as it relates to our retail engines and whatnot, take a simplified piece out of it, whatnot. But what we've really been in -- and it's easy for me to say because I'm not defending next quarter, I'm not going to be here next quarter. When you're in a transformational business, you're trying to pour more water in, a lot more water in to this future value you're building. And you know that the past is leaking out of the bottom, so we don't have the CAGR that -- until you get critical mass. Now Dan was with me when we were at U.S. Bank, and we were building -- we were the 133rd largest Visa player in the country. When we left, we were the fourth largest owner of Visa. We missed 50% of our quarters. We took the stock from $8 to $144, right? It works, right? This works, but it's a different model than show me how this thing goes against its organic (inaudible).

These guys have the assets, and you've seen the depth of the management to make it. That's the focus I would take -- that's the focus I would take on this. How much value gets created every time you're closer and closer. We're now to the point that we have the solutions for the future. If you're a bank and it costs you $250 million to run your switching infrastructure today, if you not only renew with us but you go through the effort of converting, that $250 million system is going to cost you $100 million, right? That's $150 million. Now that's not going to come initially through a huge amount of volume increase from us. It's going to come from a 60% reduction in their unit cost to do their business, therefore, the volume or at least number of transactions that were not profitable to them before that took place, now doubles or triples or quadruples in terms of what you're doing. So what we've been doing is we've been ushering in a new era, right? And that is -- now the scale, I'm really worried about. And I'm also thrilled. We support about 150 intermediaries around the world, and they're part of this hub and spoke where it goes bank -- and I'm not talking about intermediary as a core processor, I'm talking about intermediary switches and whatnot. So today, it goes bank, intermediary, whatever the branded opportunity is, Visa, Mastercard or whatever. Do you really think that the world is going to need 150 of those 10 years from now in the cloud-based, platform-driven, right? You saw Microsoft up here, right? It's -- we're going away from hub-and-spoke because that's a hub-and-spoke, and we're going to this membrane to network global structure. And I think the volumes will be 10x higher, which is really important. And I think the amount of infrastructure required to deliver it is going to be a lot less. So yes, we're going to have a lot less players yet we have an end-to-end set of solutions that the industry has to scale up for our -- to embrace the scale that we bring to the market. Long answer, but the biggest message I wanted to give to everyone today.

Okay. Did I inhibit all future questions?

GEORGE FREDERICK SUTTON: When you look at the significant contribution that real-time payments has had to growth over the past several years, where do you think the world is in terms of moving to real-time payments? Are we still in the first or second inning?

PHILIP GEORGE HEASLEY: I think we're about maybe the 1% or 2% of kind of -- maybe 1% or 2%, maybe that high.

CRAIG S. SAKS: Yes. I would say we are in the first innings. We're not even finished with the first inning. There's a very long and deep opportunity in the total journey. About 1/3 of the world's countries are live, so 2/3 have got to go. A lot of the banks still need to connect the whole fintech ecosystem and the whole digital transformation. That is made possible by these new real time examples albeit at the starting point. So I think there's a very long and very good cycle of activity over the next 3, 4, 5 years as the world catches up around the broader real-time opportunity. And the important thing is we've got some fantastic proof points in the marketplace about how real time, fundamentally, advantages and transforms economies. Examples like India are inspiring nations. I've been around the world and I'm hearing people say, we are getting a visit from the NPCI from India to come and explain to us what wonderful things they're doing. And so that's happening more and more and more. And so there's going to be a real buildup of activity and momentum which I think is really exciting. And to connect back to my partner conversation or answer, it's one of the reasons why our ability to build an ecosystem of people around us is so important because there's going to be more work than ACI can do. We want to get our IP out there quickly. Partners like Microsoft in the cloud and implementation partners and fintechs and what have you, I think, are an important part of accelerating the journey over the next 3 to 5 years.

GEORGE FREDERICK SUTTON: And one follow-up on the ACH market. I know ACI has a big, big backbone of ACH. And how much growth you've seen from same-day ACH and how ACI contribute to the federal reserves move to real time?

CRAIG S. SAKS: You're thinking fully, right?

PHILIP GEORGE HEASLEY: No. No, I'm listening.

CRAIG S. SAKS: Actually, we do not process a huge amount of ACH. We originate a lot of ACH in our digital channels environment. We bring it in and reflect it back in on the other side through the digital channels. We do some through our MTS product, which looks after the wholesale payment. But that isn't a massive part of our volumes today. So in terms of questions, is real time going to disrupt another part of our franchise vis-Ã -vis ACH? No.

PHILIP GEORGE HEASLEY: ACH is very viable as a batch broadcast of credits like payroll. But technologically, the world's light years ahead of needing ACH as a debit mentality. Different forms of immediate, faster, whatever kind of payments you want to call them, they're going to disintermediate. They will and they should disintermediate ACH relatively in a rapid fashion, right? Again, TCH is -- the major banks in the U.S. don't want to go to a cheaper unit revenue at this point. But -- and I think the Fed will be very active in kind of forcing efficiency, at least they'll be vocal here, they'll be vocal there.

JOHN KRAFT: Any last questions? Well, thanks, everybody; thanks, everybody on the webcast. We hope you leave here today as excited about our future as we are. For those of you in New York here, please join us in the next room for lunch.

PHILIP GEORGE HEASLEY: Thank you.

CRAIG S. SAKS: Thank you very much.
