But we see the planning ongoing with both SAP on an earlier stage and Wavy as well. I mean we're laying out the plans, and we'll see how this is going to fit in. It's very -- seeing these [kits] come in and then you can see, you can do the integration and then how much you can actually release some forward-looking R&D and forward-looking services and forward-looking sales, I mean it becomes very, very powerful when -- in the middle and seeing the opportunity here. You can see the power of actually doing this and coming out at the other end of the integration. So I'm generally very positive.

But actually, I should say, it's -- the positive thing -- obviously, it's a lot of work, but the positive things of doing a number of transactions like this is you can really start to plan for it. We know we're going to have a lot of integration work in the coming couple of years here. And that makes it possible for us to plan for and have a professional team really focusing on it. If you do it once, it's inclusive. It's almost harder because you cannot plan for it, you can't have resources. But here, we -- there's so much synergies, there's a lot of opportunity. We can actually plan for it in the long term, and we can resource it, which, in one way, it's harder, of course, but in one way, it's almost easier. And like anything you do effectively again, obviously, becomes -- you can create the integration machine in a much better way. All right?

PREDRAG SAVINOVIC: All right. That's very encouraging. In terms of synergies here, you're not targeting any synergies? I know ACL seems to run quite effectively based on the margins. So I assume that most synergies here will come from the revenue side in the future. And you did mention now some forward-looking R&D. But is it safe to assume that there should be some revenue synergies here? And maybe also, what degree of your customers have traffic needs in India if we can compare these a bit.

OSCAR WERNER: So revenue synergies definitely. We typically don't state those, as you know. But definitely, I mean, we see them in TWW. We see them in myElefant, and we see them in Chatlayer. And I would say, of our largest customers, the big tech customers, I would say, 100% have needs in India. I mean there's not a global brand with no customers in India, particularly on global. So on that side, yes, there's definitely opportunities. Then it's on routing. Obviously, you've seen the routes in ACL, and they have a lower cost base in India than we do. So our existing traffic, we can port over and get it more cost-efficient than we can today, and therefore, you have synergies on that front.

And then on the cost side, you're correct. I mean when you go into here and you have a very low cost base, you need to be a little bit careful about the synergies on the OpEx side and also because both ACL and SDI have opportunities there. So you're correct, a large portion being there, and we're -- to be conservative, we don't state too much on the OpEx side due to these couple of factors before we had got pretty closer to the deal. And in the long run, we see ACL as a platform for having a lower -- a lower cost base where -- which we think is very powerful and also very strategic. So if you take it, played it a bit longer, we do think that it's very powerful and make it as more competitive in general, which we can, obviously, see as synergies and something else. But we see that, and we think that will have a large impact on us going forward.

PREDRAG SAVINOVIC: All right. Super. And just one final follow-up there. You did mention the U.S. big tech. And I think you mentioned before that having access to Latin America and India is very important to your current customers. You see very strong demand for delivery in India. And at the same time, your customers like the U.S. big tech guys, they've been driving organic growth in the past quarters. You also mentioned that there's significant runway left for these customers with regards to traffic. So I'm trying just to understand the hurdles here that they see? Could this enable the likes of Microsoft, Salesforce, et cetera, to really allocate more traffic to Sinch now?

OSCAR WERNER: Yes. I mean that's -- I mean I can't say what they're going to do. But that's our goal, of course, yes. I think all these companies have significant traffic into India. I mean it's not a surprise, this is a big market, right? So all of these customers are global. They have significant traffic into India. They typically don't send it via Sinch today, and some do. But a lot of them don't because they may have local relations with companies such as ACL or others because it's just such a big market, right? This is a large portion of the world population, and they can do that. They wouldn't do that for Colombia. They don't even do that for Brazil. But for India or China or -- they may do that because it's so large companies -- or so large countries.

OPERATOR: And we have one further question in the queue so far. That's from the line of Ramil Koria of SEB.

RAMIL KORIA, ANALYST, SEB, RESEARCH DIVISION: Just a few questions from my side. Oscar, just to come back to your question on the cost efficiency. I mean 47 billion transactions, but to be the devil's advocate here, it's around about low teens of your revenues on similar transaction volumes. Is there any monetization issues here? Or is it simply so that you have more higher-value termination versus ACL?

OSCAR WERNER: Sorry, I didn't really understand the question.

RAMIL KORIA: So they have 47 billion transactions. You have 60 billion, you said, something like that? But let's take LTM numbers, you have 40 billion, and ACL posted 11%, 12% of your revenues on higher transaction volumes. So whilst more cost efficient, sure, but revenue per transaction seems way lower. Is there any sort of reason behind that? Or am I simply missing anything there?

OSCAR WERNER: It's a very good question. It is -- India is a very high-volume, low-revenue and gross profit transaction market. That is the market structure in India. That is also -- so that's just how it is. And that is driven by -- there is a lot of regulations that drives a lot of the [ignored] financial institutions to have to use text messaging and forward for a lot of different use cases. So there's just a very, very high amount of transactions. And there is even a lower cost per transaction, which both comes from the operator prices to enterprises or to people like us is low, and therefore, it drives a lot of transactions. But it's also so that, obviously, the huge populations and the economy in India makes the margin per message lower. So that's true.

On the other hand, you can see that you can run a lot of companies in a profitable way. I mean if you look at the total metrics on them, I mean, their profitability is very similar to any other company that you would see in the text message space, us or Wavy or SDI or anything else. It's just like higher number of transactions to a lower cost per -- to a lower gross profit per transaction. That's true. And that's also why we think it's for us to enter this type of a low-cost market directly ourselves is very hard because as a western company, you may have the wrong cost base. On the other hand, have that cost play, and be able to play them back into our core markets, it's obviously a very large opportunity and also a way to secure that you don't get low-cost competition that you cannot meet. So that's how I would see that. But you're correct, if you look at gross profit per message, it's very low. On the other hand, their profitability in terms of gross profit or EBITDA on total is very similar to any other market. But we see that as an opportunity because it enables us to run that type of business model and not the other way around.

RAMIL KORIA: So very clear. And then just pretty high level on the deal here. What does it really mean that it's run as a unit? And how does that differ from how you go about in other markets? And then perhaps as a follow-up to that. You've mentioned several times during the day here that this is a platform business. Should we read it that this is a way to enter other Asian markets greenfield using the superior cost structure that ACL has?

OSCAR WERNER: Yes. I think your 2 questions are connected in a way. So -- and it's good questions. It is yes. Due to the very low-cost structure here, we obviously don't want that -- we want to utilize that. And therefore, we want to kind of run it as a unit and run it -- it's not separate or standalone. But in many other transactions, we just -- we are just taking our core process that will be refined in a bit different areas and we're just implementing them and then unifying it all to 1 platform, 1 organization, 1 operations, et cetera. Here, we need to look much, much closer since it's actually a lower-cost transaction than we have, which we see as an opportunity. And here, we need to then look much, much closer. And therefore, we want to make sure we keep that low-cost base and their program as a unit and take the integration in the longer term. And the -- your other part of the question, it is correct. We do see this as an opportunity to do a organic entry into markets, which we typically before didn't have access to because it's a lower-cost base. And we see that as a very strong thing with the transactions going forward.

RAMIL KORIA: It's very clear. I have 2 more questions, hope that's fine. But on -- first off, on the due diligence here. I mean you mentioned that you've been in contact with the company through aggregation, et cetera, previously. And you've had the chance to sort of interact with competitors as well. But from conversation starting to deal closing, how has the due diligence actually been made given sort of the current situation we're in now? Have you been able to meet the company? And how thorough can you be remotely?

OSCAR WERNER: We have met this company sometimes. This process started long before COVID. And there's 2 parts in the process. One is the fact, all right, we have in India for a long time. We've been meeting the company for years. And that's obviously before COVID. So that's one part. But if you just take the proper due diligence process, it started before COVID. So several people from Sinch have been down in India and met this company several times. So yes, we have met them. Obviously, the latter part here, we have had to do remotely for many reasons. But yes, we've met the company sometimes. And we should also mention that both Roshan and Vikram are born in India. So to us, it's also closer so we've been able to -- both our CFO and CPO having -- being born in India, obviously, has made it easier for us to assess the India market as such with 2 management team members already being born in that country.

RAMIL KORIA: That's very clear. And a final one from my side here. Just looking at the purchase price, 11x EBITDA trailing. You paid 15x pre-synergies for the SAP unit. Looking at the trend since your IPO a few years ago, seems to be sloping upwards somewhat. So I mean is that sustainably on these levels bearing in mind it's a regional player, et cetera, but stripping that out? I mean have multiples, generally speaking, come up? Or is this a one-off platform transaction?

OSCAR WERNER: It's obviously hard to say, but I think this market has been, in general, have up valued a lot. And then you can see that in our own share price, I think the comparative numbers are obviously -- I don't think the comparative numbers are trending up, not the actual numbers if you only look at this, it's obviously going up. And so generally, the market has been up valued, but I think that, that maybe goes for all assets. On the other hand, it is not to say -- when you look at a multiple individually, it is very hard to say because it's -- there's so many things that goes into that, so many things that goes into that number specifically. But I think when I look at it, that all of these transactions are very highly accretive to us in any way, shape or form. And that's why we think they're very financially sound to make. And then we obviously evaluate each individual transaction on a stand-alone basis.

OPERATOR: And as there are no further questions in the queue at this time, I'll hand back to our speakers for the closing comments.

THOMAS HEATH: Thank you, everyone, for joining the call today. We appreciate your interest and encouragement. Looking forward to speaking to you again the next occasion. Thank you, everyone.

Global tech giants, Google, recently launched a number of initiatives aimed at helping businesses, job seekers, and educational institutions among others, recover from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. This move comes on the back of a number of similar ...

Global tech giants, Google, recently launched a number of initiatives aimed at helping businesses, job seekers, and educational institutions among others, recover from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. This move comes on the back of a number of similar initiatives over the years. At a virtual conference on September 15, 2020, the company announced a number of initiatives that could help business owners address the need for funding and training across various sectors. Among these are plans to help 500,000 small and medium-sized businesses get online. There’s also a partnership with Nigeria’s Ministry of Youth and Sports to provide support for 500,000 youth-owned businesses. About $3 million has been earmarked for vulnerable populations in different parts of Africa, and to support nonprofits actively engaged in the fight to help various communities and businesses recover from the effects of the pandemic. These initiatives represent Google’s latest moves to deepen its digital presence in Africa. Looking back, it seemed to really kick things into high gear in 2016 when it launched its digital skills initiative to train people in the use of various digital skills. It also kicked off its Launchpad Accelerator , a program that provides six months of equity-free support for startups. In 2016, it reportedly entered a pact with South African company, Onyx, to help with the local manufacture of smartphones. By 2017, it had reportedly provided financial support for tech hubs in Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa, Ghana, and Uganda. In 2018, it launched the Google Station, a free wifi program that has since shut down in Lagos , and looks set to be discontinued . Earlier in 2020, it also announced emergency relief funds for critically affected newsrooms across the globe. Besides Google, other big tech companies like Facebook and Microsoft have also been engaging in one form of business or social investment in Africa. The next phase for Google seems to be SMBs or SMEs, a key part of Africa’s economy. Google’s play for SMEs The International Finance Corporation (IFC) posits that SMEs account for 90% of all businesses in Africa . However, a large percentage of these businesses are unregistered and have little access to credit facilities among other benefits. In Nigeria, one of Africa’s largest markets, PwC states that SMEs account for 96% of all businesses , and about 84% of the workforce. Several of these businesses were badly hit following the onset of the pandemic, and just a few have been able to adapt. According to Ehimuan, many of these businesses have had to quickly figure out how to pivot their operations to a digital-first approach. Yet, a gap remains between those who can access these online opportunities and those who can’t. “If the economy of Africa is to recover quickly from the challenges of the period, they (SMEs) must be supported. It’s a responsibility for all because an Africa that works is great for everyone, including Google,” she asserts. Despite the fact that most SMEs are unregistered, Google says it is opening the initiatives to all small businesses that are not online. Why these moves? Historically, companies engaged in some form of corporate social responsibility (CSR) to boost the productivity of workers, and according to multinational consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), the concept of businesses giving back to their community and environment has evolved over time. According to a 2015 piece in the Harvard Business Review , though businesses are meant to engage in CSR to give back to the community and the environment, it has since become a business discipline that demands business results. So which is it for Google, Facebook, and other big tech companies with various investments in Africa? Giving back to the community, or a business strategy? A look at Internet stats in Africa offers some perspective. According to Internet world stats’ 2019 report, with a penetration rate of 39%, Africa had about 528 million Internet users, pointing to an estimated 814 million people that do not have access to the Internet. Given the relatively low purchasing power, economic struggles, and a dearth of infrastructure (power and Internet), these figures for Africa’s Internet population could also be treated with a healthy dose of scepticism. For big tech companies like Google and Facebook, Africa seems to be a big unexplored market with millions of people still connected to the Internet. Consequently, these companies have engaged in deepening Internet infrastructure and investing in technology companies, among others. Juliet Ehimuan, Google Country Manager, Nigeria, believes that Google’s various initiatives, especially during the pandemic, are expressive of the company’s commitment to helping individuals and businesses in Africa thrive again. “It is in all our interest that African economies rebound and recover,” she says. Getting businesses online Ehimuan says that Google will offer SMEs various online tools such as market finder among others, but the bigger issue has always been Internet access. A lot of work is still needed to deepen the Internet and power infrastructure. Though Google worked on Project Loon with the creation of Balloons beaming 4G signals in some parts of Kenya, they did not disclose any further expansion plans to other parts of Africa. For now, it appears Google will join Facebook to increase Africa’s subsea Internet cable capacity. The cable, Equiano, which was announced in 2019, will connect Portugal to South Africa and will have its first branching point in Nigeria. This will, however, be rendered ineffective, if the Internet capacity at Africa’s coast does not translate to better terrestrial Internet infrastructure. By Q4 2021, Equiano will add at least 100 Tbps to an existing capacity of ~170 Tbps, but only an average of 10 Tbps leaves the coast to the places where they are needed. For these cables to be effective, more investments have to be made in deepening Internet infrastructure in various structure. But then, this might mean more regulatory involvement, as well as facing the official and unofficial bottlenecks that hinder African telcos from deepening Internet infrastructure. Facebook found a way by forming strategic partnerships with the likes of MainOne and Orange, while Google’s Project Loon has found relative success in Kenya. In many ways, the activities of Big Tech companies have changed the world, but it appears a lot more changes are still to be seen in Africa. NEW EPISODE OUT! Built in Africa , a podcast by Techpoint Africa [embedded content] NEW REPORT : Nigerian startups raised $28.35m in Q2 2020; only about 4.5% of that came from local investors. Find out more in the full report . Comments

Sep 15, 2020( e27: http://www.e27.sg Delivered by Newstex) In order to help empower the APAC tech startup ecosystem, we recently launched Perks: a curated selection designed to give e27 Pro members an access to top-class products and services with over US$10,000 worth in savings. In order to do that, we have partnered with some of the most amazing solution providers in the region. We spoke to Sanjay Jha, Co-founder and CTO of LetsVenture, India's most active startup fundraising platform and the Chief Product Officer (CPO) of MyStartupEquity, to get a closer look at their products and services and to help the community understand better how MyStartupEquity can help them yield desirable results.Can you describe what your company does? What industry you are in, who your target market is?

For the last 7 years, Letsventure has been the most trusted and active platform for startup fundraising in India. We have a strong track record in building out a tech-enabled platform that has enabled over 250 startups to raise more than $200 M from thousands of angel investors, micro-VC funds and family offices. Having raised this equity, we have also noticed the gap in the market to manage this equity and that was the genesis of MyStartupEquity in late 2019. MyStartupEquity is a SaaS fintech play that is digitising, automating and securing the most valuable asset that any startup has — its own equity! This is a product to help founders, employees, investors and VCs better manage their equity in startups. What do we mean by this? Also read: A closer look at Zendesk: fostering better customer relationships for startups everywhere[1] Well, the product is designed to become the single source of truth for all matters related to a startup's cap table and ESOPs (including Phantom Stocks, Stock Appreciation Rights). By using the product, startups, right from the earliest stages to those with 10s of investors and 100s of employees with ESOPs can avoid errors that might creep into an Excel sheet and the lack of security when this Excel sheet floats into the market. Moreover, the product has a lot of tools packed in to make the life for the founder, finance and HR teams simple. Presently, MyStartupEquity has 60 startups (seed to Series D) from India, USA and Singapore using the cap table and ESOP management product.How does your product/service help companies? What gaps in the market do your products bridge?Today, the biggest problem is the information asymmetry and lack of security in the way cap tables and ESOPs are managed. Founders have a lot on their plate, finance and HR team members may change, an outsourced firm might not prioritise tasks; and all this leads to delays and errors — both forced and unforced. Let's take an example: Mark is the founder of a startup that has raised a seed round of $500,000 from friends and family and two angel investors (his ex-bosses at the big tech company he was working at before). With this, he brought on board his co-founder and CTO, Eileen and the early product team, marketing and sales team — all of whom he promised generous ESOPs since he couldn't meet market salaries. urn:contentItem:5PKR-XKM1-DY9P-N4XB-00000-00A cloud over western society;This furious polemic argues that the web threatens civilisation, says Hugo Rifkind2017-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:36ZLexisNexisSATURDAY REVIEW;FEATURESPg. 18,19A cloud over western societyThis furious polemic argues that the web threatens civilisation, says Hugo RifkindHugo Rifkind

World Without Mind

The Existential Threat of Big Tech by Franklin Foer

Jonathan Cape 272pp; £18.99

Franklin Foer is furious. It takes a while to appreciate he is furious, granted, because he is a ponderous writer, and in World Without Mind: The Existential Threat of Big Tech he is apt to get distracted from his fury with lengthy passages about things such as the history of bookshelves, or whether Des-cartes really built a robot that looked like his dead daughter, Francine, which was thrown off a boat. (No.) But furious he definitely is. As the subtitle suggests, he believes that tech companies are ruining the world.

"Oh, that again," you might think. Foer, though, is well placed to make this criticism, because before tech companies started ruining the world, they first ruined his. Foer resigned/was fired in 2014 as editor of The New Republic, one of those liberal New York magazines that people pretend to read. The magazine's new proprietor, Chris Hughes, a founder of Facebook, had bought an old media company and was set upon turning it into a new media company. Foer, who oozes old media despite not really being old enough, was far from keen on this.

Foer believes that tech companies have degraded the intellectual discourse of not just social media users, but civilisation. They have, he argues, assaulted the very foundation of knowledge. For Foer, the foundational text of Silicon Valley was The Whole Earth Catalog, a countercultural magazine run by Stewart Brand in the late 1960s, which sought to spread niche knowledge to the hippy masses. Brand came up with the maxim "information wants to be free". Foer puts this as the inspiration behind Google's desire to scan every book in existence, waging war on the concept of copyright. The idea is that maximum human knowledge should lead to maximum human enlightenment.

Yet that's not what happened. For one thing, when you have endless available information you hit what David Foster Wallace called "total noise", an impenetrable blurt of everything. The historical problem of scarcity of information - which early tech evangelists sought to solve - has morphed into a scarcity of attention.

People need to filter. The tech answer is an algorithm, but algorithms are not neutral. Foer points out that Netflix and Amazon offer recommendations to their users, but there the similarities end. Amazon directs its users to more familiar products (one third of its purchases come from its recommendations), whereas subscriptionbased Netflix directs users to the unfamiliar because blockbusters cost more to stream.

Foer has a slightly tweedy disdain for the philistines of tech. You can feel the sneer in his quoting of Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder, when he complains about physical books, "turning the pages … the book is always flopping itself shut at the wrong moment".

Coming from a man whose firm sells 40 per cent of all books bought, this hurts.

Even so, Foer's denunciation of online journalism, which comes in his book's best chapter, is powerful. He notes that a memoir by the critic Alfred Kazin recalls that the fee for a book review in The New Republic of the 1930s was $150. Despite 80 years of inflation, this is also, dollar for dollar, the fee for a book review for the same magazine's website. Everything is falling apart.

"The core insight of Upworthy, Buzzfeed, Vox and other emerging internet behemoths," he writes, "was that editorial success could be engineered." A company can study which topics get the most clicks, and which writers. This has led to the phenomenon of headlines with a "curiosity gap". Upworthy once garnered 6 million clicks from the headline "9 Out Of 10 Americans Are Completely Wrong About This Mind-Blowing Fact". The fact in question was merely a dry statistic about income inequality. At the time, the company would create 25 headlines per story, and study which one did best.

Meanwhile, another internet trend has been to render articles "untethered entities" in much the same way that Apple's iTunes model ripped singles out of albums. The upshot, with both, is that the fun stuff soars and the worthy stuff fades away.

Foer's first contention is that this leads to nonsense. For example, last year's inconsequential story about a Minnesota dentist shooting a lion (Cecil, you remember) generated 3.2 million stories online, which he calls "a deluge of ephemera dissecting the ephemeral". His second, more contentious contention is that it led to the election of Donald Trump, because the news chased easy hits and Trump's outrages gave them.

Foer argues that the internet is polarising western societies. "Facebook has created two hive minds each residing in an ecosystem that nurtures head-nodding agreement and penalises dissenting views." We pick a tribe and conform, and cannot break free to empathise with another.

Foer's solutions to all this are largely regulatory, technical and American, and might not terribly interest British readers. His main concession to a British edition is a foreword that, I must confess, gave me the hump. In it, he suggests that the British press was once a great national strength "like France's wine or Switzerland's timepieces", but that it has terribly declined over the past 20 years (ie while I've been working in it). As it happens, I think he's wrong, or not wholly right. Newspapers in the 1990s could be every bit as crap as they sometimes manage to be today.

Still, his book comes as a rousing recommendation of a subscription model newspaper that avoids the ravages of virality. You're reading one. Well done you.

urn:contentItem:5XR3-4WR1-JCMN-Y2YJ-00000-00ACLU sues Homeland Security over 'stingray' phone surveillance2019-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:36ZLexisNexisACLU sues Homeland Security over 'stingray' phone surveillanceAdrian Potoroaca

Dec 12, 2019( TechSpot: http://www.techspot.com Delivered by Newstex) Cutting corners: Stingrays are nothing new, but their use by law enforcement is still shrouded in secrecy, even after numerous attempts to regulate them. Civil right advocates have long called for more transparency on the matter, but after seeing how difficult it is to get access to public records pertaining to the use of cell site simulators by CBP and ICE, the American Civil Liberties Union are suing the two government agencies in an effort to bring that information to light. Privacy seems to be at a premium these days, and even big tech companies that are the biggest proponents of more stringent rules[1] don't always practice what they preach.

Just this past week Apple inadvertently revealed through a lawsuit that it is routinely collecting phone calls and messages of its employees. The Immigration Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) have been involved in numerous privacy debacles over the last few years, but now the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) is suing[2] them for failing to produce public materials that disclose how they use "stingrays."Stingrays are essentially cell sites that act like the real ones used by wireless carriers, so they can be used to trick phones into connecting to them. Law enforcement agencies can then identify, locate, and track those phones, but in the process they also get information about phones of innocent people, which introduces the potential for abuse and mishandling of the collected data.According to a 2016 report[3] from the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, ICE and CBP had already spent $13 billion on 92 stingrays. Keep in mind that these are also able to observe call records and text messages, and history shows the two agencies aren't doing their best job to protect[4] the data they collect.An ACLU spokesperson notes "the public has a right to know if and how often ICE and CBP are using Stingrays, which were originally intended for use by the military and intelligence agencies, for civil immigration enforcement operations." The civil liberties group is asking the two agencies to sound off on what steps they have taken to ensure stingrays aren't used against innocent bystanders, and whether they disclose their use in immigration court proceedings. We know Stingrays have been in use[5] by law enforcement around the country to conduct surveillance operations, but this could quickly turn into a national security issue. Last year, the Department of Homeland Security said it had knowledge of several unauthorized stingrays[6] operating in Washington, DC, leading to speculation that they may have been used by foreign spies. urn:contentItem:5W9D-V7X1-DXH2-6000-00000-00A Comparison Of Royal Visits; YouTube Strikes Down Conservative Commentator, Steven Crowder; Border Officials Sounding The Alarm After More Than 144,000 Migrants Were Apprehended In May; Media Doxxes "Drunk" Pelosi Video Creator; Straight Pride Backlash2019-06-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:36ZLexisNexisWATTERS WORLD8:00 PM ESTKatie Nicholl; Joe Concha; Tonya Reiman; Michael Knowles; Shawn Brooks; John HugoNEWSInternational060801cb.251A Comparison Of Royal Visits; YouTube Strikes Down Conservative Commentator, Steven Crowder; Border Officials Sounding The Alarm After More Than 144,000 Migrants Were Apprehended In May; Media Doxxes "Drunk" Pelosi Video Creator; Straight Pride BacklashJesse Watters; Marc Thiessen; Richard Fowler; Aisha Hasnie; Lou Dobbs; Lynnete "Diamond" Hardaway; Rochelle "Silk" Richardson

RICK BARRY, RETIRED PROFESSIONAL BASKETBALL PLAYER: Youth unemployment is down. We just need to get back to the values of what we had in the past. And if we do that, I think we'll be fine.

MARK LEVIN, FOX NEWS HOST: Been a pleasure.

BARRY: Thank you, my pleasure.

LEVIN: Appreciate it. See you next time on "Life, Liberty & Levin."

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST, WATTERS' WORLD: Welcome to WATTERS' WORLD. I'm Jesse Watters. Two big exclusives tonight. We have the man who was doxxed by the media for publishing that drunk Nancy Pelosi video and the leader of the Straight Pride March is in WATTERS' WORLD, so stick around.

All right, comparing state visits. That's the subject of tonight's "Watters' Words." President Trump and President Obama were both invited for State Dinners with the Queen.

So for fun, we decided to compare how each visit went using the exact same barometers so even the partisans can't argue, so you can see the performances side by side. We begin with the toast. Here's President Barack Obama toasting Her Majesty the Queen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: To Her Majesty, The Queen, for the vitality of the special relationship between our peoples, and in the words of Shakespeare, "To this blessed plot, this earth, this realm, this England." To the Queen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: That was so awkward. You don't toast the Queen while the anthem is playing. "The Globe and Mail" headline says it all, "How not to toast the Queen: Obama's awkward Royal gaffe."

Here was President Trump's toast.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The brave sons of the United Kingdom and the United States, who defeated the Nazis and the Nazi regime and liberated millions from tyranny. The bond between our nations was forever sealed in that great crusade.

As we honor our shared victory and heritage, we affirm the common values that will unite us long into the future -- freedom, sovereignty, self- determination, the rule of law and reference for the rights given to us by Almighty God.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: And you see the clink, very smooth. Now, let's look at the gifts that were given. Barack Obama gave the Queen an iPod with his speeches on it. And Donald Trump gave the Queen a Tiffany brooch. Not sure what a brooch is, but I think it's some small pocketbook, a brooch, okay, and we will let the audience decide who gave the better gift.

Both Presidents famously signed the guest book at Westminster Abbey. My sister is a big-time liberal, sent me an image mocking Trump's inscription that he said the Abbey was a special place. So I immediately wondered, "Well, what did Obama write?" It turns out Obama signed the wrong year in the guest book. Barack signed the book 2008 when he was there in 2011.

Finally, turning to the First Ladies, let's do a little style comparison. Here is Melania in an ivory and navy suit. Very chic, the hat and everything. Here's Michelle, in a more colorful dress which the wind got ahold of, again, style is very personal, so everyone is going to have a different opinion. But I think you know what mine is.

Here with reaction, media reporter for "The Hill," Joe Concha, Fox News contributor and American Enterprise Institute fellow, Marc Thiessen and Royal expert Katie Nicholl, and she is the author of "Harry: Life, loss, and love." Okay, Katie, let's begin with the gifts. I think the brooch or whatever you call it was a hit compared to an iPod. What did you think?

KATIE NICHOLL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I completely agree with you. It's a brooch. And the reason you probably don't know what it is because it's quite an old-fashioned piece of jewelry, so a young woman don't really wear brooches that is very much of the Queen's generation and the Queen loves them because of their intricacy. They sit beautifully on the lapel of a dress or a coat.

She uses them to really send a message out so when she visits Canada, she will wear the maple leaf brooch. When she is in --

WATTERS: Right, and I don't think she likes the iPod. Is that what I'm picking up?

NICHOLL: I am not saying -- listen, I tell you, the Queen does not know how to record a voicemail message on a phone. So he she is going to open up an iPod.

WATTERS: I don't know. That was a long shot. What about the style? You saw Melania looking very gorgeous in the very well-fitting, sleek outfit. Michelle Obama, I'm not sure. You know, she has a different sense of style. How did the styles play in Britain?

NICHOLL: Listen, they wore completely different styles. I noticed two things. When Michelle was here for the State Dinner, she wore an off the shoulder dress. It was crossed over at the front, and that's a bit risque because you don't show your shoulders at a State Dinner. She also didn't wear a hat once during the visit, while Melania pulled up the stops.

Not only did she go for a Britannia-themed Gucci dress when she left and --

WATTERS: And I'm not even sure it's fair that we're showing that side by side because we had the little wind incident there, which you know, she wasn't responsible for.

All right, Joe, you saw how the media treated this visit. You know, they talked about the protests. How do you think it was covered?

JOE CONCHA, MEDIA REPORTER, THE HILL: The protests were covered as mass protest, Jesse, right? And when you compare them to a year ago when the President went there, they were about a third this time around then they were back in 2018.

WATTERS: So people dislike him less now.

CONCHA: It seems that way.

WATTERS: Okay.

CONCHA: Or just apathy, whatever. But the blimp, they kept concentrating on the Trump baby blimp, like you're looking at the OJ Bronco all over again from 1994 like there's the blimp again.

WATTERS: Right, and you're there to commemorate, you know, D-Day, a very special moment in the Alliance, and they're focused on an inflatable piece of plastic.

CONCHA: Yes. It was like the Michael Avenatti of blimps, like I turned on cable news and there's the blimp.

WATTERS: I know. It's like is everywhere you saw, you just saw the blimp. All right, Marc. For me, this was about a special invitation between two countries that share a common language. Common institutions common heritage, commemorating 75 years after America helped save Great Britain essentially. And the Queen invited the President of the United States of America, the office and all the millions of people that President Trump represents that was the point of this visit. Not a blimp, you know, not the gift, none of that.

MARC THIESSEN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, and that you're absolutely right on that one completely over the heads of all of Trump's critics in Britain, you know, you had the Mayor of London attacking him. You had Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of the opposition who boycotted the dinner.

And as you pointed out, she invited the President of the United States, not the man who occupies the office. She was honoring the country and the man who leads it and the American people who are her allies and who we fought this great battle together.

And so when Jeremy Corbyn and some of the opposition leaders don't show up at the dinner, they're not disrespecting Donald Trump, the person; they're disrespecting America. They're disrespecting the office of the Presidency.

And so I thought it was quite -- you know, the focus on a lot of our media over here is on you know, Trump punching back at some of these guys because he is a counter puncher, but I was shocked, you know, the Royal Family treated him beautifully.

But I was shocked by how the political establishment and Britain behaved absolutely shamefully towards him.

WATTERS: Yes. Because if you're the Mayor of London and two days before the leader of the free world who saved your behind 75 years before comes to visit and you're trash talking him and comparing him to Stalin. What kind of -- I thought the British were supposed to have manners, Marc? I mean, that's not the way you welcome your ally.

THIESSEN: Well, maybe that was a compliment because Stalin was their ally then.

WATTERS: Yes, I mean, and you know what did Trump say? What did Trump say? He said he is like de Blasio, but even dumber and shorter?

CONCHA: And that's the thing, right?

THIESSEN: Exactly.

CONCHA: Because Mayor Khan got a lot of attention, and we hung on every word that he had to say, no media outlet, I saw, Jesse shared what his approval rating is.

WATTERS: What is it?

CONCHA: You've got 32 percent satisfactory rating by Londoners. He is a de Blasio.

WATTERS: So you're saying President Trump's approval is higher than Khan's. I mean, I wish that had been reported.

CONCHA: Yes, President Trump is at 44 percent in the Real Clear Politics index of polls. He is at 48 percent in a Harvard poll, that's the highest since integration. He is trending up ironically, at a time when everybody is talking impeachment.

WATTERS: And Bill de Blasio has gone from zero percent to 2 percent. So, way to go, Bill. All right, Katie, Joe and Marc, thank you guys.

A special handshake for a very special relationship. President Trump kicking off his official State Visit to the U.K. greeting Her Royal Highness, Queen Elizabeth, with what looks like a little bit of a fist bump. So what's going on there? Let's ask our body language expert Tonya Reiman.

All right, Tonya, you see the President approaching, and you know, he extends the hand, and everybody on the internet was looking at it because I think he was grasping the hand here. What was going on there, did you see?

TONYA REIMAN, BODY LANGUAGE EXPERT: Yes. So when you see that, what wound up happening is he is used to a full handshake, right? You see she extends just her fingertips. Yes. So we do this, right. So this becomes odd for him because he's normally used to a regular hand.

But so this is where you see that he can supplicate, he can actually go down and do an alpha-kind of beta-hybrid when he does this. So what did he do? He grabbed the hand.

WATTERS: Right, he grabs the hand.

REIMAN: And then he shook up and down a little bit.

WATTERS: He did.

REIMAN: Yes, and then he went side to side because he wasn't really sure.

WATTERS: He went side to side.

REIMAN: He went um and then uh.

WATTERS: Because she presented her hand like this. No one ever presents the President with her hand like that.

REIMAN: Well, the Queen does, and that's her role. So she was kind of going, "Oh, this is a normal behavior." And he had to then back up and go, "Wait a minute, who am I with?" So yes, give the --

WATTERS: No one ever knows how to greet the Queen. There's always issues. I think Michelle Obama got attacked because she put her hand on the Queen's back at one point, and that's a Royal no-no.

REIMAN: So did Donald Trump.

WATTERS: He did it, too.

REIMAN: He did.

WATTERS: No American knows what to do when they're presented with a Royalty.

REIMAN: He needs to be absolutely --

WATTERS: We have no clue what the etiquette is. We always mess it up. All right, Camilla winked. It was like the wink heard around the world. Let's take a look at this interaction here.

So you see Camilla off to the right. Oh, did you see that little wink there? Let's see that again. Can we roll that back? Let's see the little wink as she leaves. Slow it down. And then -- what was the wink about?

REIMAN: You know, that was really a good thing to see from her because people interpret her as so like, stiff and hard. And when you see her wink like that, what you notice first is the smile. So she has this big smile. We don't know for sure who she is winking at. But she has this big smile that comes in naturally. And when you see the smile first and then the wink, you know, it's a genuine movement.

WATTERS: Yes, because the fake news media was trying to spin this, "Oh, this is a cry for help."

REIMAN: Oh, no, that was a joke. I well -- I don't know if that was a joke, but it was not. I mean, obviously, she put on a very big smile. It was a genuine smile. And she winks and that's the way that you say something like, "Hey, we have this bond, this relationship," some secret.

WATTERS: Some would say, a special relationship.

REIMAN: Yes, perhaps.

WATTERS: All right, Tonya Reiman, there she is. Body language expert extraordinaire, knocking down the fake news media. Tonya, thank you.

REIMAN: Thank you.

WATTERS: YouTube strikes down conservative commentator, Steven Crowder and the man who the media doxxed for creating the drunk Pelosi video speaks to WATTERS' WORLD in an exclusive, next.

WATTERS: Steven Crowder is a conservative comedian who makes YouTube videos, very popular guy, almost four million followers, and he's been going after vox.com reporter Carlos Maza, who is a liberal guy. He is a gay Latino.

So the vox.com reporter, Maza was very offended and he demanded that YouTube ban Crowder's videos. And YouTube responded saying that Crowder didn't violate their terms of service, but was harmful to the community. And they've prevented him from making money on his videos until he changes some of the merchandise that he sells.

Now, many people are wondering how YouTube decides what's harmful, considering some of the left-wing comedians, they have some material on there that's also kind of bad. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEPHEN COLBERT, CBS SHOW HOST: You're turning into a real [bleep] hater. We're not broadcasting right now. So I'd say, "What does Vladimir Putin's [bleep] taste like?

SAMANTHA BEE, COMEDIAN: You know, Ivanka, that's a beautiful photo of you and your child. But let me just say one mother to another, do something about your dad's immigration practices. You feckless [bleep]. He listens to you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: So Crowder says he's been targeted for just being a conservative comedian. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN CROWDER, COMEDIAN: This isn't just for conservatives now. It's everybody. It's everybody who creates original content because we have not been attacked for being conservative, mind you. At least that's not what they said. It's offensive jokes.

So if you do jokes that are offensive, they can completely remove your ability to make a living.

This isn't Carlos Maza. This is absolutely Vox, a billion dollar company that is going after a voice that is more effective than them at dealing with their misinformation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: Joining me now with their take on all of this, the host of "The Michael Knowles Show," Michael Knowles and Fox News contributor, Richard Fowler. All right, Michael. I don't think it's that funny what he was saying about this vox.com guy. Perhaps he has some sort of comedic license because he's a comedian, but I didn't laugh about it. But where do you draw the line? He didn't violate the standards, but he was harmful to the community. No one knows what YouTube means anymore. How do you see it?

MICHAEL KNOWLES, HOST, THE MICHAEL KNOWLES SHOW: Of course YouTube is just using this as an excuse to declare all-out war on conservatives. They admit that Crowder did not violate any of the rules. They said they were going to leave his videos up. Then vox.com launched another campaign, and they said they were going to demonetize him and they're taking away lots of other videos.

YouTube is going after all conservatives and the timing here is not coincidental. This was not some exasperated frustration from the vox.com journalist. This was a premeditated calculated campaign to take conservatives off of YouTube.

It occurred two days before Pride Month began, and it occurred two weeks before the first Democratic presidential debate. What this is going to lead to is as the 2020 race heats up, YouTube is going to get rid of conservative videos, they've already said that they are going to start promoting authoritative videos meaning "The New York Times" or CNN or any other left-wing news source. It's going to be one giant undisclosed in- kind contribution to Democrats going into 2020, and it's time that we, conservatives litigate them into dust.

WATTERS: Yes. Richard, so this reporter used to work at Media Matters. He obviously has a huge agenda. He is admitting it. I mean, he is tweeting out that he wants conservatives to be de-platformed. He is bragging about it.

And then in another tweet, he is talking about throwing milkshakes on everybody. You know, when they come up to you in the street, you throw a milkshake. So to say he is, you know, the sensitive guy that gets offended. You know, it's tough on the internet. I know what Crowder said was, was homophobic and maybe not that cool if you're on the receiving end of it.

But the internet is a tough place and the right battles left and this is the age we live in. How do you see it?

RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Listen, I can't speak to this particular reporter and what he is alleging or not alleging. But YouTube's policy change is something that YouTube is allowed to do. They're a private company. I'm not really sure on what grounds conservative will have to litigate YouTube. Remember, they are a private company. This is their First Amendment right.

When Crowder signed up to be a YouTuber, he signed just like I did. They signed a user agreement.

WATTERS: What if they are applying their censorship standards unevenly based on politics?

FOWLER: Well, no, no. YouTube, when you sign to be part of the YouTube community, you sign a user agreement, and as part of that user agreement, they say they could limit how and what type of videos they put up, and what they deem to be offensive and non-offensive, and that is their First Amendment right as a company.

It's the same as when Blockbuster was the largest distributor of rental videos. They don't have to carry every single video ever produced, just like when Barnes and Noble was the number one book store in the in the country. They didn't have to carry every book that was ever published.

WATTERS: Yes, Richard, there's a lot of young Americans who don't have any idea what Blockbuster Video is. They don't remember what it was like on a Saturday night when you had to walk to Blockbuster and rent a video.

FOWLER: That is the reason why I am using that as an empirical example, just like it is -- I get that.

WATTERS: I know. So Michael, what do you say to Fowler who says that, you know, it's a private company, and they can adjudicate any issues the way they see fit, because, you know, it's not the government.

KNOWLES: That isn't true. What they're doing is violating the law.

FOWLER: Which law?

KNOWLES: Big technology broadly -- the Communications Decency Act of 1996. So what big tech does and YouTube in particular, is they say that they are just an open technology platform. So they don't need to worry about any of the liabilities that go along with publishers -- defamation, copyright infringement, intellectual property, any of that.

Then they go into a California courtroom -- Facebook did this just last year -- and they say, actually, they are publishers, because they want to be protected by the regulations that govern publishers. They cannot have it both ways.

The reason for that law in 1996 was to allow the internet to grow and to innovate, and create billion dollar companies like YouTube.

But now they are clearly acting as publishers, they are exerting editorial influence. They're not even posting rules. They're just saying that their editors will decide what they like and what they don't like. They are a publisher.

FOWLER: No, that's not true.

WATTERS: I'll give you the last word, Richard. Go ahead. Thirty seconds.

FOWLER: That's absolutely not true. What they did is they updated their policy on hate speech. And that's how those videos are demonetized which is nothing about that their editor is doing anything. They had a policy change on how they dictated videos in their community. And based on that, those videos are demonetized and they have the ability to do that under the First Amendment.

WATTERS: All right, gentlemen, thank you guys very much for a very robust debate.

FOWLER: Good to see you, Jesse.

WATTERS: Coming up, Lou Dobbs in the house. And Lou gets personal like you've never seen him before. You don't want to miss that. And later, the leader of the very controversial Straight Pride Parade is here to explain himself.

AISHAH HASNIE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Live from "America's News Headquarters," I'm Aishah Hasnie. President Trump receiving praise from Republicans on Capitol Hill after striking an 11th hour deal with Mexico. The U.S. promising to hold off on tariffs that were set to go into effect on Monday.

In return Mexico has agreed to ramp up its efforts to stop the flow of illegal migration across into the U.S. To help make that happen, Mexico will deploy its National Guard and crackdown on human traffickers.

A subway car derailing at Boston sending nine people to the hospital, a tenth person was also injured but refused medical treatment. According to emergency officials, none of the injuries are life-threatening. The Green Line Subway car derailed inside a tunnel near Kenmore Square. The cause is still under investigation. I'm Aishah Hasnie, now back to WATTERS' WORLD.

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

JOHN SANDERS, ACTING CUSTOMS AND BORDER PROTECTION COMMISSIONER: We are in a full blown emergency and I cannot say this stronger. The system is broken. We are well beyond capacity in all of our southwest border custodial facilities. This ongoing crisis has placed a tremendous strain on our limited resources and operational effectiveness.

(END AUDIO CLIP)

WATTERS: Border officials sounding the alarm after more than 144,000 migrants were apprehended in May. It's the highest number in 13 years, a 32 percent increase just from April. And check this out, Customs and Border Patrol releasing this video from Tuesday showing a group of over 130 Central Americans walking around the end of the partially built border wall and then they just surrender to agents right there. They want to be caught.

Joining me now, host of "Lou Dobbs Tonight" on the Fox Business Network, Lou Dobbs. What do you think about the video? They just walk right around it?

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS HOST: Well, I think that's the intelligent thing for them to do. What would have been commensurately intelligent would be for the Border Patrol to have been ready at the end of the wall to deal with the onslaught of illegal immigrants.

WATTERS: So the President comes out and he threatens tariffs on Mexico. That's the only thing that seems to be working because the Mexican delegation scrambles as fast as they possibly can over to the White House to start negotiating.

DOBBS: Yes, well, they stopped. Remember they stopped first with Nancy Pelosi to beg her to find some way to give them relief.

WATTERS: She doesn't want to do anything either.

DOBBS: Well, I don't think she wants to do anything for the United States. But she might be open to serious consideration of the Mexican interests that seems to be who she is aligned with, as the rhinos and the Senate, led by Mitch McConnell, they are lined up with the cartels.

This is no longer about being lined up with just the Chamber of Commerce and big business. The radical Dems and the rhino Republicans are straight up wanting to help and support the cartels as much as they can.

WATTERS: I've said this before. The only people winning at the border are the cartels, the traffickers and the human smugglers. They want open borders, and by giving it to them, they're just making more cash.

DOBBS: Yes. It's a very simple proposition, isn't it? And I love the fact that there are people running around Washington, D.C., Jesse now saying, "You know, I think we've got a crisis." That's what the President declared four months ago.

This is as moronic a display that I've ever seen in covering the Federal government. The bureaucracy is brain dead. The permanent bureaucracy, the political leadership, I mean this Kevin McAleenan, acting head of DHS, I can't figure out whether he's a politician or he is running as an investment banker, what he wants to do.

WATTERS: He is certainly acting. That's what we can say.

DOBBS: Well, it is. And it is not a great performance.

WATTERS: No.

DOBBS: Let's face it.

WATTERS: It's not. I want to move on to something a little more uplifting.

DOBBS: Okay.

WATTERS: I saw a veteran, he was 93 years old, a British guy. And you know, he is shaking hands with the President and the First Lady and gets a little flirtatious. Take a look at this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If I was 20 years younger.

TRUMP: Oh, you can handle it, no question about it.

WATTERS: I mean, only a 93-year-old World War II can get away with that with the First Lady.

DOBBS: Well, it tells you a little bit how he got to 93 that he survived. The man is still all man as that generation was. My gosh. To think of these heroes from the United States, from our allies, the President celebrating them and commemorating that extraordinary moment in our history. It's truly wonderful.

WATTERS: What did you think about the President's performance overseas?

DOBBS: This is -- this man stood with the Queen. She has hosted all sorts of dignitaries and leaders from the world. A 90-minute private conversation with the Queen. They obviously reveled in one another's time together. It's just -- and Boris Johnson fell in line, little Sadiq Khan.

WATTERS: Little Sadiq. What did he say about de Blasio? He is just as dumb, but shorter.

DOBB: Yes, and I think he is -- he may be even dumber.

WATTERS: That's true.

DOBBS: But we should get metrics on it.

WATTERS: People have been e-mailing me, Lou, they want to know about Lou and what you do on the weekends. You're a mystery man around here, extremely successful, but they want to know, what's the real Lou Dobbs like off camera?

DOBBS: Well, every bit is brilliant and charming as on camera.

WATTERS: I knew you were going to say that.

DOBBS: Look, I usually I'm in my jeans and on the farm and I love to climb on a tractor and play farmer.

WATTERS: Really? What kind of crops do you have on the farm?

DOBBS: We have we have hay and horses and grandkids.

WATTERS: That's -- you've got to water those crops often.

DOBBS: You better believe it.

WATTERS: Those kids are growing. All right, Lou Dobbs, everybody, man of the people.

DOBBS: Yes sir.

WATTERS: He has got his hands in the soil every weekend.

DOBBS: You bet. I can't think of a higher compliment than to be a man of the people.

WATTERS: All right, there he is, Lou Dobbs. Thank you very much for joining WATTERS' WORLD.

DOBBS: Thank you. Appreciate it. Good to see you, Jesse.

WATTERS: You, too.

Lou, thank you very much. Kanye West back at it again with the MAGA hats. Diamond and Silk react to that, but first, an exclusive interview with the man who the media doxxed for creating the drunk Pelosi video.

WATTERS: Remember this video that came out about two weeks ago? Purportedly showing how speaker Nancy Pelosi drunk. Well, it was slowed down to make her speech seem slurred. And here's the real video from that event. As you can see, she's just fine moving at a normal speed.

Fast forward to last week when "The Daily Beast" doxxed a man who say that created the quote unquote "Drunk Pelosi" video. They revealed his personal identity and information. And that man, Shawn Brooks joins me now in an exclusive phone interview.

All right, Shawn, did you create this slow-mo Pelosi video?

SHAWN BROOKS, DOXXED BY THE DAILY BEAST (via phone): No, I did not create the video, I just shared.

WATTERS: Who created the video?

BROOKS: I have no idea. It was shared on the page from another admin that received it via an e-mail.

WATTERS: All right, so you run a page -- a politics page. Someone shared it with the page and then you pushed it out live, right?

BROOKS: Yes, I pushed -- I shared it on my page, almost like eight hours later, but the video was on the national page and it became -- people started sharing it. And then it just blew up.

WATTERS: It went viral. It went crazy.

BROOKS: Yes.

WATTERS: People who don't know what you look like, you're an African- American. Not a Democrat. Obviously not a fan of Nancy Pelosi. Am I right about that?

BROOKS: Yes, I don't -- I'm not a fan of Pelosi. I don't have much -- I mean, besides was in the news, I am not -- I don't have any issues with her like I am not anti or I've got to go out and try to hurt her.

WATTERS: Right.

BROOKS: You know?

WATTERS: Right.

BROOKS: And I am pro-Trump, so --

WATTERS: Okay, so you're a black Trump supporter, and you put out this video and it goes absolutely viral all over the world. And all of a sudden, what? You get a phone call from reporters, trying to find out what? How -- what happened next?

BROOKS: Well, the video was out there. I started getting messages and phone calls from different reporters, and one specific guy, Kevin Poulsen. He was -- I blocked him on Twitter. I blocked him all over the place because he kept pounding me like he was pretty much harassing me, and he wanted me to talk to him.

WATTERS: Okay.

BROOKS: At this point, I wasn't aware that I was being named the guy, like I heard people saying I did it.

WATTERS: Right.

BROOKS: I was like, I guess he must connect it with me because I just sent out a tweet to one -- it was just there -- it was when I first came out and said that the video was a fake, and that they tried to reach me for comments.

So I was just replying to the comment saying, you didn't try to reach the page, because I'm one of the admins.

WATTERS: Okay.

BROOKS: I didn't post the video, but I am an admin and I checked messages and you didn't try to reach out.

WATTERS: Okay, so you're getting hounded by this "Daily Beast" reporter and you realized at the time when you pushed it out there that it was slowed down, right?

BROOKS: Yes.

WATTERS: Okay. And you weren't doing this -- were you doing this just for fun or you were just you know, a video you're trying to get out there and get some clicks? Or was there some sort of diabolical motivation?

BROOKS: No, I shared it because it was funny. And I saw on Twitter how everyone was saying, "Is she drunk?" So I just asked the same question.

WATTERS: Okay, so you're contacted by "The Daily Beast," And they were on the phone with you for a long time, wrote this huge story about you and named you, named where you lived, talked to an ex-girlfriend. How does that make you feel?

BROOKS: Well, I feel violated because like the guy got much -- like a lot. He exaggerated a lot of the details. He made up -- he took quotes from one question and added it to another situation like with the -- he put together -- he tried to make me out to be a misogynist the way -- because of my current legal situation that happened with my ex-girlfriend, and he tried to find an old post on Facebook and put it together as, "Oh, this guy hates women."

And the way it -- and then the racist thing, the African-American comment in the beginning of his article, makes me ought to be -- it's like a -- it sounded like a recent article that he tried to push out that he has feeling about me being a Trump supporter.

WATTERS: Okay.

BROOKS: That was his main issue with it.

WATTERS: So you think he did a dishonest job reporting the story. Do you feel like you're threatened now that your identity is out there?

BROOKS: Well, I've lost some work. Some people that I did work with go, "Oh, I can't believe you used to be Trump supporter. I didn't know that." Like, it was like I lost a few jobs. I have been threatened. People have threatened me saying that, "Oh, we've got to find him and get him." Stuff like that

My family members have -- won't even talk to me now. They call me a race trader. Bad for the culture or something like that -- crazy stuff. I mean, it's just been kind of rough. Like I really had no one to really talk to about this one. It blew up like I couldn't really have anyone on the phone, somebody to say, "Hey, can I just get this off my chest." Because everyone, you know, has turned on me.

You know, Bette Midler could tweet out some fake news. And, you know, no one really goes to see who created the fake news that Bette Midler tweeted out, you know, it seems to be a little unfair when these things happen. But hang in there, Shawn, and we appreciate you coming into WATTERS' WORLD.

WATTERS: Okay. All right. Well, listen, I think --

WATTERS: Very much. All right. That's all for us tonight. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. Follow Rookie on Instagram, too @rookiewatters and remember, I'm Watters' and this is my world.

urn:contentItem:5JYV-YGS1-DYY9-J1TC-00000-00A Computer Tried (and Failed) to Write This Article2016-06-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:35ZLexisNexisA Computer Tried (and Failed) to Write This ArticleAdrienne LaFrance


None of this turned out how it was supposed to.

Here I am, a human, writing a story that was assigned to a machine. If I'd published what the computer came up with, you'd be reading something like:
"content that was that communications and everything that makes on a person what they're are also to be in the Internet in the fact about it is that models are technologication of the same that its also from the most computer."


A machine really did come up with that garbage. But let me back up for a second.
A little over a year ago, I started asking around-among computer scientists at universities and tech companies, mostly-to see if someone would help me design and carry out a weird little experiment I had in mind. I wanted to train a machine to write like me.
The idea was this: We'd give Robot Adrienne a crash course in journalism by having it learn from a trove of my past writings, then publish whatever Robot Me came up with.
This isn't a far-fetched idea, and not just because robots have a long track-record of automating human labor. There are already algorithms that can write stories. At The Los Angeles Times, there's a program that   reports breaking news about earthquakes. Bots can easily be programmed to write other basic stories-things like box scores and real estate listings, even obituaries. In January, Wired had a news-writing bot produce   a remembrance of Marvin Minsky, the artificial intelligence pioneer. The result was a little dry compared with the obituary for Minksy written by a human at The New York Times-but the machine version was decent. Last year, NPR's Scott Horsley   raced a bot to report quarterly earnings for the diner chain, Denny's. Horsely's version had more stylistic flourish, but the bot filed its story in two minutes flat-five full minutes before Horsely, basically an eternity in radio time.
Impressive as these news bots may be, I didn't want Robot Adrienne to be a formulaic speed machine with a Mad Libsian approach to reporting. Instead, I wanted to use a neural network, a computer model inspired by the human brain, that could assess a bunch of input data, infer its structure, then represent that information with its own original output.
This approach could ostensibly produce something more complex and less predictable than the bots that spend their days filling in the blanks. Using a neural network to generate language is, on the simplest level, how human babies learn about language, to they model input from adults, then generate their own output. "If you think about that loop, babies are taking information in, encoding it, and expressive speech is the output," said Kirsten Cullen Sharma, a neuropsychologist who focuses on child development. "This is how the brain develops, [and determines] what connections the brain decides to keep."
My interest in a neural-net configuration for my experiment was somewhat selfish. These networks are so cool in part because when you give a machine a gob of data, that information is all the machine has to make sense of the world. So when you look at the eventual output, you have the potential to learn quite a bit about the input. If a computer can learn how to write simply by analyzing one person's work, that machine is theoretically in a position to reveal otherwise subtle idiosyncrasies about the input data-a particular writer's structural conventions might become obvious, and other stylistic tics illuminated.
If a robot's eventually going to take my job anyway, why not get it to help me become a better writer first?
Last fall, Google agreed to help me. This was great news. The company's commitment to A.I. research is well documented: It has taught computers to   dream, to   defeat humans in abstract strategy games, and to   compose music. Artificial intelligence is arguably at the heart of   everythingGoogle is and does.
But after months of back and forth, with little explanation, the company said it wouldn't be able to help me with my experiment after all. (Understandable, of course, that one of the world's leading tech firms might have other priorities.) I had similar experiences with several other big tech companies that focus on artificial intelligence.
Last month, my editor suggested I ask the writer and technologist   Robin Sloan, one of those rare humans who always seems to be effortlessly dabbling in some crazy-brilliant side-project, yet is still somehow kind enough to maybe consider helping a random reporter obsessed with building a robot version of herself. As it happened, Sloan had lately been conducting a similar language-generation experiment of his own: tinkering with a recurrent neural network and a massive chunk of text from the annals of science fiction as a way to see what kind of story a computer mind might write.
So I begged him to help me, and told him about the massive plain text doc of my writing I had all ready to go.
"I am totally game to train an RNN on your Adrienne Corpus," Sloan told me. "I would definitely set your expectations low-there is no way in which its output will seem like 'a piece by Adrienne'-but at the same time, the things these networks capture-the 'flavor' of text-are, to me, still pretty remarkable."
So I sent Sloan the document, which contained painstakingly copy-and-pasted text from two years of published stories-almost all the stuff I'd written for The Atlantic since 2014, totaling 532,519 words. Sloan turned to an open-source Torch-RNN package-   which you can find on GitHub, courtesy of the Stanford computer scientist Justin Johnson-and he got to work.
"One of the magical things about this moment in deep learning is that many of core tools have been packaged up and made accessible to enthusiast-level programmers (like me), but that doesn't mean it's exactly straightforward," Sloan explained. "I had to install and configure a scientific computing package called Torch and a bundle of sub-packages that specifically support neural networks." He also used a computer with a very fast GPU-experimentation still would have been possible with the kind of processor in a powerful laptop, for instance, but it would have taken a lot longer.
Here's what it looks like when you train a neural network. (Robin Sloan)
It became clear pretty quickly that half-a-million words, or about 3 MB of text, wasn't enough for the neural network to learn language the way I'd hoped. When Sloan entered a prompt-"The most interesting thing is..."-here's what the machine spit out in various iterations of the initial experiment:

So far, the ersatz version of me has quite a bit to learn.

urn:contentItem:5WKD-JDR1-JCMN-Y4X6-00000-00A Congressman just asked Apple about those iCloud storage alerts that keep popping up on your iPhone, and Apple didn't seem sure how to respond (AAPL)2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:35ZLexisNexisA Congressman just asked Apple about those iCloud storage alerts that keep popping up on your iPhone, and Apple didn't seem sure how to respond (AAPL)Lisa Eadicicco

Jul 16, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Shutterstock Rep. Greg Steube (R-FL) questioned an Apple executive about iPhone alerts encouraging him to pay $0.99 for iCloud storage during a hearing on Tuesday examining whether large tech platforms hinder innovation and entrepreneurship within the industry. Apple[1] only provides 5GB of free iCloud storage to customers, whereas Google offers 15GB of free cloud storage to it users.

Apple previously upgraded the amount of local storage in most iPhone models after facing criticism for years. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[2] If you own an iPhone, you're probably familiar with that notification reminding you that you're almost out of iCloud storage. That's because Apple only offers 5GB of free storage and requires you to sign up for a monthly plan if you want additional space, with the lowest option starting at $1 per month for 50GB. That's presumably what Rep. Greg Steube of Florida was referencing when he questioned Kyle Andeer, Apple's vice president of corporate law and chief compliance officer on Tuesday. Andeer was testifying alongside executives from Google, Facebook, and Amazon at a Congressional subcommittee hearing about large tech platforms and the influence they have on innovation and entrepreneurship. When questioning Andeer, Steube said he often sees an alert asking him to pay $0.99 for iCloud, adding that the alert doesn't disappear unless the $0.99 is paid. "I've got a very important question for Apple that I believe is on the mind of all Americans," Steube said. "Why do you keep getting that alert for the iCloud, for the $0.99 on the iCloud? All the time, constantly, constantly. Until you pay the $0.99 for the iCloud, and then you're paying the $0.99 for iCloud but you're not using it," he said. Andeer said he was not aware of the details around Steube's question and that he would get back to him with additional information. The comments underscore the criticism[3] Apple[4] has faced in recent years over the amount of storage it offers for free compared to rivals like Google. Those who sign up for a Google account get 15GB of free storage across services including Google Drive, Google Docs, and Gmail. Apple does offer more free storage than Dropbox, however, which only provides users with 2GB of complimentary space. Apple also recently expanded the amount of free storage to 200GB for students, but standard customers are still limited to the 5GB of space Apple has been offering since it unveiled iCloud in 2011. Apple has not made any public indications that it plans to change that anytime soon. But after it was widely criticized for only offering 16GB of storage in the entry level model of the iPhone, it changed its lowest storage option to 32GB starting with the iPhone 7 in 2016.
